<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>78<br><h1> 右 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右%20%23kanji">Right</a></h1>When thinking of the key word right、 in order to avoid confusion with the previous frame、 take advantage of the doublemeaning here、 too。 Imagine a little mouth hanging down by your side—like a little voice of conscience—telling you the right thing to do。 Here the second stroke should reach out to the right and be drawn slightly longer than the first。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 う">ウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 ゆう">ユウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/右 みぎ">みぎ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>79<br><h1> 有 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有%20%23kanji">Possess</a></h1>The picture here is of someone with a slab of meat dangling by the side、 perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist。 Think of it as an evil spirit in possession of one’s soul、 who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh meat to hang by one’s side until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon departs。 Take careful note of the stroke order。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有 ゆう">ユウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有 う">ウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/有ある">あ－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>80<br><h1> 賄 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄%20%23kanji">Bribe</a></h1>To the left we have the primitive for a shellfish、 and to the right the kanji we just learned for possess。 Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word possess、 and now expand your image of shells to include the ancient value they had as money （a usage that will come in very helpful later on）。 Now one who is possessed by shells is likely to abandon any higher principles to acquire more and more wealth。 These are the easiest ones to bribe with a few extra shells。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄 わい">ワイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/賄まかなう">まかな－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>81<br><h1> 貢 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢%20%23kanji">Tribute</a></h1>A tribute has a kind of double－meaning in English： honor paid freely and money collected by coercion。 Simply because a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consolation to the masses who must part with their hard－earned money。 Little wonder that this ancient craft of getting money by calling it a tribute has given way to a name closer to how it feels to those who pay it： a tax。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢 こう">コウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢 く">ク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貢みつぐ">みつ－ぐ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>82<br><h1> 項 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項%20%23kanji">Paragraph</a></h1>To the right we see a head and to the left an element that means craft。 When we think of a paragraph、 we immediately think of a heading device to break a text into parts。 （Think of the elaborate heads often seen at the start of medieval manuscripts and the task becomes easier still。） Just where and how to do it belongs to the writer’s craft。 Hence、 we define paragraphing as the “heading craft” to remember this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/項 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>83<br><h1> 刀 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀%20%23kanji">Sword</a></h1>Although this kanji no longer looks very much like a sword、 it does have some resemblance to the handle of the sword。 This is to our advantage、 in that it helps us make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji。 In the form of the kanji、 this primitive means a dagger。 When it appears to the right of another element、 it is commonly stretched out like this 刂 and takes the sense of a great and flashing saber、 a meaning it gets from a character we shall learn later （frame 1671 剣）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刀 かたな">かたな</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>84<br><h1> 刃 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃%20%23kanji">Blade</a></h1>Think of using a dagger as a razor blade、 and it shouldn’t be hard to imagine cutting yourself。 See the little drop of blood clinging to the blade？<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃 じん">ジン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刃 は">は</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>85<br><h1> 切 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切%20%23kanji">Cut</a></h1>To the right we see the dagger and next to it the number seven whose primitive meaning we decided would be diced （frame 7 七 ）。 It is hard to think of cutting anything with a knife without imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs。 Only let us say that he has had too much to drink at a party、;grabs a dagger lying on the mantelpiece and starts dicing up everything in sight、 starting with the hors d’oeuvres and going on to the furniture and the carpets…。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切 せつ">セツ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切きる">き－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/切きれる">き－れる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>86<br><h1> 召 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召%20%23kanji">Seduce</a></h1>A sword or dagger posed over a mouth is how the character for “beckoning” is written。 The related but less tame key word seduce was chosen because it seemed to fit better with the—how shall we put it？—Freudian implications of the kanji。 （Observe if you will that it is not sure whether the long slender object is seducing the small round one or vice versa。）  The primitive meaning remains the same：seduce。 Just be sure to associate it with a very concrete image。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/召めす">め－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>87<br><h1> 昭 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭%20%23kanji">Shining</a></h1>Let the key word suggest shining one’s shoes、 the purpose of which is to seduce the sun down on them for all to see。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昭 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>88<br><h1> 則 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則%20%23kanji">Rule</a></h1>The character depicts a clam alongside a great and flashing saber。 Think of digging for clams in an area where there are gaming rules governing how large a find has to be before you can keep it。 So you take your trusty saber、 which you have carefully notched like a yardstick、 crack open a clam、 and then measure the poor little beastie to see if it is as long as the rules say it has to be。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/則 そく">ソク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>89<br><h1> 副 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副%20%23kanji">Vice</a></h1>The key word vice has the sense of someone second－in－command。 The great and flashing saber to the right （its usual location、 so you need not worry about where to put it from now on） and the wealth on the left combine to create an image of dividing one’s property to give a share to one’s vice－wealthholder。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/副 ふく">フク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>90<br><h1> 別 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別%20%23kanji">Separate</a></h1>In the Old East、 the samurai and his saber were never separated。 They were constant companions、 like the cowboy of the Old West and his six－shooter。 This character depicts what must have been the height of separation－anxiety for a samurai： to be bound up with a rope and unable to get at his saber leaning only a few feet away from him。 Look at that mouth bellowing out for shame and sorrow！ Note the order in which the element for tied up is written— just as it had been with the character for ten thousand。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別 べつ">ベツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/別わかれる">わか－れる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>91<br><h1> 丁 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁%20%23kanji">Street</a></h1>The picture here is of a street sign on a long pole： Hollywood and Vine、 if you please、 or any street that immediately conjures up the image of a street sign to you。  Used as a primitive、 we change the meaning of the key word and take the shape to signify a nail or a spike。 Should it happen、 on reviewing、 that you find the pictographs get jumbled、 then think of jerking a street sign out of the ground and using it as a nail to repair your garage roof。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁 ちょう">チョウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丁 てい">テイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>92<br><h1> 町 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町%20%23kanji">Village</a></h1>Street signs standing at the corner of the rice fields depict the village limits。 （Remember what was said earlier： when used as a primitive、 a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町 ちょう">チョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/町 まち">まち</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>93<br><h1> 可 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可%20%23kanji">Can</a></h1>Remember the story about the “Little Engine that Could” when you hear this key word、 and the rest is simple。 See the determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the mountain—”I think I can、 I think I can。。。”—spitting railroad spikes out of its mouth as it chews up the line to the top。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/可 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>94<br><h1> 頂 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂%20%23kanji">Place on the head</a></h1>The key word is actually a formal metaphor meaning “humble acceptance。” Reading off the two primitive elements in the order of their writing、 we have： nail 。 。 。 head。 As in “hitting the nail on the head。” Now one presumes that most people can handle metaphors、 but if you were to run into a dimwit working in a hardware store who only knew the literal meaning of things、 and were to ask him、 in your best Japanese、 to place on your head a nail、 he might miss the point and cause you considerable torment。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂 ちょう">チョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂いただく">いただ－く</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/頂 いただき">いただき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>95<br><h1> 子 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子%20%23kanji">Child</a></h1>This kanji is a pictograph of a child wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young children who cannot get around by themselves。 The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air； the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up； and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother’s neck。  As a primitive、 the meaning of child is retained、 though you might imagine a little older child、 able to run around and get into more mischief。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 し">シ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 す">ス</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/子 こ">こ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>96<br><h1> 孔 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/孔%20%23kanji">Cavity</a></h1>Probably the one thing most children fear more than anything else is the dentist’s chair。 Once a child has seen a dentist holding the x－rays up to the light and heard that ominous word cavity、 even though it is not likely to know that the word means “hole” until it is much older、 it will not be long before those two syllables get associated with the drill and that row of shiny hooks the dentist uses to torture people who are too small to fight back。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/孔 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>97<br><h1> 了 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了%20%23kanji">Complete</a></h1>Learn this character by returning to frame 95 子 and the image given there。 The only diff erence is that the “arms” have been left off （actually、 only tucked inside）。 Thus a child with its arms wrapped up into the back－sack is the picture of a job successfully completed。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/了 りょう">リョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>98<br><h1> 女 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女%20%23kanji">Woman</a></h1>You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting woman drawn behind this character、 with two legs at the bottom、 two arms （the horizontal line） and the head poking out the top。 A little farfetched、 until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes。 Remembering the kanji is easy； being able to write it beautifully is another thing。 The primitive meaning is the same： woman。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 じょ">ジョ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 にょ">ニョ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 にょう">ニョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 おんな">おんな</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/女 め">め</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>99<br><h1> 好 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好%20%23kanji">Fond</a></h1>The phrase “to be fond of someone” has a natural gentleness about it、 and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giv－ ing us the related term “to fondle。” The character likens it to a woman fondling her child。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好このむ">この－む</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/好すく">す－く</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>100<br><h1> 如 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/如%20%23kanji">Likeness</a></h1>Pardon me if I revert to the venerable old Dr。 Freud again、 but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette。 For instance、 the fact that things like the mouth of a cave served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening through which a woman gives birth。 Hence、 in order to be reborn as an adult、 one may have to pass through the psychological equivalent of the womb、 that is、 something that bears a likeness to the opening of the woman from whom you were born。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/如 じょ">ジョ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/如 にょ">ニョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>101<br><h1> 母 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母%20%23kanji">Mama</a></h1>Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for woman in it、 the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a mama。 Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother’s breast has aff orded some scholars of comparative linguistics a way to explain the presence of the same word across a wide range of language－groups。  As a primitive we shall add the meaning of breasts in accord with the explanation given above。 Take careful note of the fact that the form is altered slightly when this kanji serves as a primitive、 the final two dots joining together to form a longer stroke。 An example follows in the next frame。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母 ぼ">ボ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/母 はは">はは</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>102<br><h1> 貫 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫%20%23kanji">Pierce</a></h1>If one is asked to think of associations for the word pierce、 among the first to come to mind is that of piercing one’s ears to hold earrings、 a quite primitive form of self－mutilation that has survived into the 21st century。 The kanji here is read、 top to bottom： mama 。 。 。 oyster。 All you need to do is imagine piercing an ear so that it can hold a mother－of－pearl （actually、 a mamaof－pearl） you have just wrested from an oyster。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貫つらぬく">つらぬ－く</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>103<br><h1> 兄 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兄%20%23kanji">Elder brother</a></h1>By now kanji like this one should “look like” something to you even though it is more of an “ideogram” than a “pictograph。” The large mouth on top and the human legs below almost jump off the page as a caricature of elder brother、 the one with the big mouth （or if you prefer a kinder image、 the one who “has the say” among all the children）。  As a primitive this character will take the meaning of teenager、 in accord with the familiar image of the big mouth and the gangling、 clumsy legs。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兄 けい">ケイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兄 きょう">キョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兄 あに">あに</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>104<br><h1> 克 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/克%20%23kanji">Overcome</a></h1>In this frame we get a chance to use the kanji we just learned in its primitive meaning of teenager。 The needle on top indicates one of the major problems confronting the teenager growing up in today’s world： drugs。 Many of them will fall under the shadow of the needle at some time during those tender years、 but only when a whole generation rises up and decides that “We Shall Overcome” the plague、 will the needle cease to hang over their heads、 as it does in this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/克 こく">コク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>105<br><h1> 小 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小%20%23kanji">Little</a></h1>The sense of little in this character is not the same as “a little bit。” That meaning comes in the next frame。 Here little means “small” or “tiny。” The image is one of three little drops、 the first of which （the one in the middle） is written larger so that the kanji has some shape to it。 The point of writing it three times is to rub the point in： little、 little、 nothing but little。 The primitive of the same shape keeps the same meaning。 Written above a horizontal line、 its form is slightly altered、 the last two strokes turning inwards like this： 聹。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小ちいさい">ちい－さい</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 こ">こ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/小 お">お</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>106<br><h1> 少 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/少%20%23kanji">Few</a></h1>First we need to look at the fourth stroke、 the drop at the bottom that has been extended into a longer diagonal stroke leaning left 。 This happens because a single、 isolated drop will never appear beneath its relative primitive in its normal size、 for fear it would drop off and get lost。 As for the meaning、 let the tiny drop indicate a further belittling of what is already little—thus making it a few of something little。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/少 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/少すくない">すく－ない</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/少すこし">すこ－し</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>107<br><h1> 大 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/大%20%23kanji">Large</a></h1>Here we have a simple pictograph of a person、 taking up the space of an entire character and giving it the sense of large。 It should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched arms。  As a primitive、 we need a diff erent meaning、 since the element representing the human person will come up later。 Therefore、 this shape will become a large dog or、 if you prefer、 a St。 Bernard dog。 In frame 238 犬 we will explain why this choice was made。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/大 だい">ダイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/大 たい">タイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/大 おお">おお</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/大おおきい">おお－きい</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/大おおいに">おお－いに</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>108<br><h1> 多 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/多%20%23kanji">Many</a></h1>“Many moons ago、” begins much of Amerindian folklore—a color ful way of saying “Once upon a time” and a great deal of help for remembering this kanji。 Here we have two moons （three of them would take us back to the beginning of time、 which is further than we want to go）、 lacking the final stroke because they are partially hidden behind the clouds of time。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/多 た">タ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/多おおい">おお－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>109<br><h1> 夕 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夕%20%23kanji">Evening</a></h1>Just as the word evening adds a touch of formality or romanticism to the ordinary word “night、” so the kanji for evening takes the ordinary looking moon in the night sky and has a cloud pass over it （as we saw in the last frame）。  The primitive keeps the same meaning and connotation as the kanji。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夕 せき">セキ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夕 ゆう">ゆう</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>110<br><h1> 汐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汐%20%23kanji">Eventide</a></h1>In the next lesson we will meet the character for morning－tide and the element for drops of water。 Meantime we have a perfect blend of picture and idea in this kanji to play on the English word for nightfall、 eventide： drops of water inching their way up the shore in the evening。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>111<br><h1> 外 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外%20%23kanji">Outside</a></h1>On the left 、 the primitive for evening、 and on the right、 that for the magic wand。 Now、 as every magician worth his abracadabra knows、 bringing your magic wand out into the evening air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to stay indoors。 Hence、 evening and magic wand takes you naturally outside。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外 がい">ガイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外 げ">ゲ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外 そと">そと</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外 ほか">ほか</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外はずす">はず－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/外はずれる">はず－れる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>112<br><h1> 名 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/名%20%23kanji">Name</a></h1>Perhaps you have heard of the custom、 still preserved in certain African tribes、 of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his newborn child on the night of the child’s birth、 to whisper into its ear the name he has chosen for it、 before making his choice public。 It is an impressive naming custom and fits in tidily with the way this character is constructed： evening 。 。 。 mouth。 At evening time、 a mouth pronounces the name that will accompany one throughout life。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/名 めい">メイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/名 みょう">ミョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/名 な">な</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>113<br><h1> 石 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石%20%23kanji">Stone</a></h1>With a mouth under a cliff、 what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern、 before which a great stone has been rolled so that none may enter。 Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures、 in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted over the tales of the Arabian Nights should be enough to push the stone aside。 But take care—the cliff is steep、 and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below。 This is the one and only time that the second stroke in cliff will reach over to the middle of the horizontal stroke。 If you think of the edge jutting outwards （in keeping with the story above）、 the problem should be taken care of。 The stone is a quite common primitive element、 which is not restricted to great boulders but used of stones or rocks of any size or shape。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 せき">セキ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 しゃく">シャク</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 こく">コク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/石 いし">いし</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>114<br><h1> 肖 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖%20%23kanji">Resemblance</a></h1>The word resemblance should suggest、 among other things、 a son’s resemblance to his father。 A “chip off the old block” is the way we often put it、 but the character is more simple。 It speaks of a little bit of flesh。  When used as a primitive、 the sense of resemblance is replaced by that of spark or candle。 （If you want an explanation： the kanji for moon also carries a secondary sense of fire、 which we omitted because we are keeping that meaning for other primitives。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肖 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>115<br><h1> 硝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/硝%20%23kanji">Nitrate</a></h1>The word nitrate should immediately suggest a beaker of nitric acid、 which、 as every high－school chemistry student knows、 can eat its way through some pretty tough substances。 Here we imagine pouring it over a rock and watching the sparks fly as it bores a hole through the rock。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/硝 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>116<br><h1> 砕 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕%20%23kanji">Smash</a></h1>We begin with the two elements on the right、 baseball and needle。 Since they will be coming together from time to time、 let us give the two of them the sense of a game of cricket in which a needle is laid across the wicket。 Then imagine using a rock for a ball。 A smash hit would probably splinter the bat in all directions、 and a smashing pitch would do the same with the needle wicket。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕くだく">くだ－く</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砕くだける">くだ－ける</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>117<br><h1> 砂 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂%20%23kanji">Sand</a></h1>Good sand for beaches has few or no stones in it。 That means that all of us whose feet have been spoiled by too much time in shoes don’t have to watch our step as we cavort about。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 さ">サ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 しゃ">シャ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/砂 すな">すな</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>118<br><h1> 削 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/削%20%23kanji">Plane</a></h1>Long before the invention of the carpenter’s plane、 people used knives and machetes （or here、 sabers） to smooth out their woodwork。 If you have ever seen the process、 you will have been amazed at the speed and agility with which the adept can plane a hunk of wood into shape。 Indeed、 you can almost see the sparks fly from their sabers。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/削 さく">サク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/削けずる">けず－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>119<br><h1> 光 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/光%20%23kanji">Ray</a></h1>There are really only 2 primitives here、 little and human legs。 The 4th stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aes－ thetics。 （If that doesn’t make sense、 try writing the kanji without it and see how ugly the results look、 even to your beginner’s eye。） Now if you have wondered what those little particles of “dust” are that dance around in the light－rays that come through the window and fall on your desk、 try imagining them as little and disembodied human legs、 and you should have no trouble with this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/光 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/光ひかる">ひか－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/光 ひかり">ひかり</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>120<br><h1> 太 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/太%20%23kanji">Plump</a></h1>“Plump” is one of those delightful English words that almost sound like their meaning。 No sooner do you hear it than you think of a round and ample－bodied person falling into a sofa like a large drop of oil plopping into a fishbowl—kerrrr－plump！<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/太 たい">タイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/太 た">タ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/太ふとい">ふと－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/太ふとる">ふと－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>121<br><h1> 器 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/器%20%23kanji">Utensil</a></h1>The picture in this kanji is not a pleasant one。 It shows a large and fluffy St。 Bernard dog stretched out on a table all stuff ed and stewed and garnished with vegetables、 its paws in the air and an apple in its mouth。 At each corner of the table sits an eager but empty mouth、 waiting for the utensils to arrive so the feast can begin。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/器 き">キ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/器 うつわ">うつわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>122<br><h1> 臭 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/臭%20%23kanji">Stinking</a></h1>This character is a bit friendlier to the animal world than the last one。 Our friend the St。 Bernard is alive and well、 its nose in the air sniffing suspiciously after something stinking somewhere or other。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/臭 しゅう">シュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/臭くさい">くさ－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/臭におう">にお－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>123<br><h1> 妙 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妙%20%23kanji">Exquisite</a></h1>The primitive for woman is on the left （there and at the bottom of another primitive is where you will always find her）、 and to the right the element for few。 When we refer to a woman as exquisite、 we mean to praise her as the sort of person we meet but few and far between。 If you are interested in etymologies、 it might help to recall that the Latin phrase lying at the root of the English word exquisite carries this same sense of “seeking out” the rare from the ordinary。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妙 みょう">ミョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>124<br><h1> 省 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/省%20%23kanji">Focus</a></h1>When we think of focusing on something、 we usually take it in a metaphorical sense、 though the literal sense is not far behind。 It means to block out what is nonessential in order to fix our eye on a few important matters。 The kanji suggests picking up a few things and holding them before one’s eye in order to focus on them better。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/省 せい">セイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/省 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/省かえりみる">かえり－みる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/省はぶく">はぶ－く</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>125<br><h1> 厚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厚%20%23kanji">Thick</a></h1>When we refer to someone as thick－skinned or thick－headed、 we are usually quick to add—even if only under our breath— something about their upbringing。 Perhaps it is because deep down we cherish the belief that by nature people are basically tender and sensitive。 Be that as it may、 the Japanese character for thick depicts a child abandoned out on the wild cliff s、 exposed to the heat of the sun、 and thus doomed to develop a head and skin as thick as the parent who left it there。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厚 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厚あつい">あつ－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>126<br><h1> 奇 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/奇%20%23kanji">Strange</a></h1>The elements we are given to work with here are St。 Bernard dog and can。 Lots of phrases pop to mind to attach these words to the keyword、 but they end up too abstract because of the word can。 It is important in such cases （and there will be plenty of them as we go along） to stick closely to the elements、 in this case、 mouth and nails。 Now all we need do is create a fictitious “Strange But True” column in the Sunday funnies、 featuring a St。 Bernard whose mouth has been nailed shut because he was hitting the brandy keg around his neck too hard。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/奇 き">キ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>127<br><h1> 川 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川%20%23kanji">Stream</a></h1>We have taken the image of a river stream over into English to describe things that fall down in straight lines、 or ripple along in lines。 All of this is more than evident in the kanji given here、 a pictograph of a stream。  As a primitive、 this character adds to the meaning of stream the more vivid image of a flood。 Note、 however、 that there are certain small changes in the writing of the element、 depending on where it appears relative to other elements： on the left 、 it is written 川 on the top、 it is written 巛 on the bottom、 it is written 職<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川 せん">セン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/川 かわ">かわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>128<br><h1> 州 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/州%20%23kanji">State</a></h1>Here we see drops of land （little islets） rising up out of a stream、 creating a kind of sandbar or breakwater。 Ever wonder how the state－line is drawn between states separated by a river？ If there were little drops of land as in the kanji、 there’d be nothing to it。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/州 しゅう">シュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/州 す">す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>129<br><h1> 順 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順%20%23kanji">Obey</a></h1>In primitive language、 this character would read stream 。 。 。 head。 And that turns out to be convenient for remembering its meaning of obey。 Either one obeys the person who is head of an organization or else obeys by following the stream of opinion （“current” practice、 we call it）。 Both these senses come together in this kanji。 。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/順 じゅん">ジュン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>130<br><h1> 水 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水%20%23kanji">Water</a></h1>This character、 which looks a bit like a snowflake、 is actually a pictograph of water—not any particular body of water or movement of water、 but simply the generic name for water。 Should you have any difficulty remembering it、 simply think of a walking stick being dropped vertically into the water、 sending droplets out in all four directions。 Then all you need to learn is how to write it in proper order。  As a primitive、 this character can keep its form、 or it can be written with three drops to the left of another primitive、 like this： 氵。 This latter、 as we will see、 is far more common。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水 すい">スイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/水 みず">みず</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>131<br><h1> 氷 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷%20%23kanji">Icicle</a></h1>The appearance of the primitive for water in its full form tells us that we have something to do with water here。 The extra drop to the left 、 added as a second stroke、 changes the picture from a splash caused by a walking stick dropped into water to form an icicle。 If it helps、 when you hold an icicle up to the light、 you can usually see little crystallizations of five－pointed stars inside of it、 which is the shape we have in this kanji。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 ひょう">ヒョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 こおり">こおり</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/氷 ひ">ひ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>132<br><h1> 永 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永%20%23kanji">Eternity</a></h1>This kanji also uses the full form of water、 though its meaning seems to have nothing at all to do with water。 Remember what William Blake said about seeing “infinity in a grain of sand and eternity in an hour”？ Well、 reading this character from top to bottom、 we see “eternity in a drop of water。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永 えい">エイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/永ながい">なが－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>133<br><h1> 泉 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉%20%23kanji">Spring</a></h1>Call to mind the image of a fresh、 bubbling spring of water、 and you will probably notice how the top of the spring you are thinking of、 the part where the “bubbling” goes on、 is all white。 Happily、 the white is just where it should be、 at the top、 and the water is at the bottom。  We will keep this image of a spring when using this kanji as a primitive、 but not without first drawing attention to a slight change that distinguishes the primitive from the kanji。 The final 4 strokes （the element for water） are abbreviated to the three small drops that we learned earlier as the kanji for little、 giving us： 聽。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉 せん">セン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泉 いずみ">いずみ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>134<br><h1> 原 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原%20%23kanji">Meadow</a></h1>Though the kanji is broad enough to embrace both meanings、 the meadow you should imagine here is not a flatland plain but a mountain meadow in the Austrian Alps。 （Perhaps the opening scene of “The Sound of Music” will help。） Simply think of little springs bubbling up across the meadow to form a sort of path that leads you right to the brink of a precipitous cliff。 Now if you can see Schwester Maria skipping along merrily、 dodging in and out of the springs、 and then falling headlong over the cliff、 you have a ridiculous story that should help fix this kanji in memory。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原 げん">ゲン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/原 はら">はら</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>135<br><h1> 願 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願%20%23kanji">Petition</a></h1>A meadow and a head are all we are given to work with in the kanji for petition。 Since the key word already suggests something like a formal request made of some higher power、 let us imagine a gigantic Wizard－of－Oz head located in the middle of the flowery meadow we used in the last frame。 Then just picture people kneeling hopefully before it、 petitioning for whatever it is they want。 （The scarecrow wanted brains、 the lion、 courage、 and the tin man a heart。 What about you？）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願 がん">ガン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/願ねがう">ねが－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>136<br><h1> 泳 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳%20%23kanji">Swim</a></h1>The primitive to the left 、 you will recall from frame 130 水、 represents water。 To the right、 we see the kanji for eternity。 Knowing how much children like swimming、 what could be a better image of eternal bliss than an endless expanse of water to swim in without a care in the world？<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳 えい">エイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泳およぐ">およ－ぐ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>137<br><h1> 沼 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼%20%23kanji">Marsh</a></h1>Unlike the meadow with its cliff s、 the marshlands are low and near a source of water that feeds them until they get soggy through and through。 Why certain land becomes marshy is probably due to the fact that it felt thirsty、 and so tried its best to seduce the water over to its side。 But、 like most inordinate seductions、 the last state of the victim is worse than the first。 Hence the slushy marsh。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沼 ぬま">ぬま</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>138<br><h1> 沖 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖%20%23kanji">Open sea</a></h1>This kanji could hardly be simpler。 The key word open sea readily suggests being out in the middle of a great body of water。 Thinking of it in this way should avoid confusion with the kanji for “open、” which we will meet later on。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖 ちゅう">チュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沖 おき">おき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>139<br><h1> 江 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江%20%23kanji">Creek</a></h1>Unlike the river、 the ocean、 the lake、 and the pond、 the creek is often no more then a dribble of water trickling down a small gully。 While the geological history of the larger bodies of water is hard to surmise sometimes、 all of us know from our childhood how creeks are made。 You probably even dug one or two in your time。 All you need to do is find a mainstream of water somewhere and dig a little path into dry land。 The creek is thus a lesson in water－craft、 as this kanji would agree。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/江 え">え</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>140<br><h1> 汁 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁%20%23kanji">Soup</a></h1>To make soup、 one begins with water and then starts adding things to it、 often left overs from the icebox。 This is how the thick soup or stew called “seven－in－one” is made。 This kanji does it three better、 giving us a ten－ingredient soup。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁 じゅう">ジュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汁 しる">しる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>141<br><h1> 潮 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮%20%23kanji">Tide</a></h1>Before we get to explaining this character、 take a look at it and see if you can figure out the primitive elements on your own…。 On the left is the water—that much is easy。 On the right we have only one primitive、 the kanji for morning learned back in frame<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮 ちょう">チョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/潮 しお">しお</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>142<br><h1> 源 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源%20%23kanji">Source</a></h1>With the advice of the last frame in mind、 it is easy to see water and meadow in this character for source。 Both in its etymology （it has a common parent with the word “surge”） and in popular usage、 source suggests the place water comes from。 In this kanji、 it is under the meadow、 where we just saw it breaking the surface in those bubbly little springs。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源 げん">ゲン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/源 みなもと">みなもと</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>143<br><h1> 活 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活%20%23kanji">Lively</a></h1>When we speak of a lively personality or a lively party、 we immediately think of a lot of chatter。 This kanji depicts the idea of lively by having tongues babble and splash around like flowing water。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/活 かつ">カツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>144<br><h1> 消 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消%20%23kanji">Extinguish</a></h1>Among the many things water is useful for is extinguishing fires、 and that is just what we have here。 First of all、 take the water at the left as the drops of water that are used to depict water in general。 In the best of all possible worlds、 the most effi － cient way to extinguish a fire would be to see that each drop of water hits one spark of the conflagration。 An unthinkable bit of utopian fire fighting、 you say to yourself、 but helpful for assigning this key word its primitives。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消きえる">き－える</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/消けす">け－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>145<br><h1> 況 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況%20%23kanji">But of course</a></h1>This key word is a connector used to link contrasting phrases and sentences together with much the same flavor as the English phrase but of course。 Just picture yourself ready to go off on your first date as a teenager、 and having your mother grill you about your manners and ask you embarrassing questions about your hygiene。 “Did you have a good shower？” “But of course…、” you reply、 annoyed。 So water and teenager combine to give us but of course。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/況 きょう">キョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>146<br><h1> 河 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河%20%23kanji">River</a></h1>The character in this frame represents a step up from the stream we met in frame 127 川； it is a full－sized river。 The water to the left tells us what we are dealing with、 and the can at the right tells us that our “little engine that could” has now become amphibious and is chugging down the Mighty Mississip’ like a regular riverboat。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/河 かわ">かわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>147<br><h1> 泊 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泊%20%23kanji">Overnight</a></h1>When you stop at an inn for an overnight rest、 all you expect is a bit of water for a wash and a set of clean white sheets to wrap your weary bones in。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泊 はく">ハク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泊とまる">と－まる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泊とめる">と－める</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>148<br><h1> 湖 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/湖%20%23kanji">Lake</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 old 。 。 。 flesh。 You have heard of legends of people being abandoned in the mountains when they had become too old to work。 Well、 here is a legend about people being set adrift in the waters of a stormy lake because their flesh had gotten too old to bear the burdens of life。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/湖 こ">コ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/湖 みずうみ">みずうみ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>149<br><h1> 測 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/測%20%23kanji">Fathom</a></h1>Connoting the measurement of the depth of water、 the key word fathom begins with the water primitive。 To its right、 we see the compound－primitive for rule （frame 88 順） which we learned in the sense of a “ruler” or “measure。” Hence、 when we rule water we fathom it。 What could be simpler？ But be careful； its simplicity is deceptive。 Be sure to picture yourself fathoming a body of water several hundred feet deep by using a ruler of gargantuan proportions。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/測 そく">ソク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/測はかる">はか－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>150<br><h1> 土 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/土%20%23kanji">Soil</a></h1>I don’t like it any more than you do、 but this kanji is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be： a mound of soil piled on the ground。 All I can recommend is that you memorize it as it is。 Anyway、 it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it、 even if you try。  As a primitive、 the sense of soil is extended to that of ground because of its connection with the kanji for the same （frame 515 地）。 From there it also takes the added meanings of dirt and land。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/土 ど">ド</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/土 と">ト</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/土 つち">つち</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>151<br><h1> 吐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吐%20%23kanji">Spit</a></h1>We have here a rather small mouth （it is always compressed when set on the left ） next to a much larger piece of dirt。 It is not hard to imagine what you might do if you got a mouth full of dirt。 As least I know what I would do： spit it out as fast and far as I could！<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吐 と">ト</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吐はく">は－く</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>152<br><h1> 圧 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/圧%20%23kanji">Pressure</a></h1>One of the things that causes the erosion of soil is the excessive pressure of the topsoil on the lower soil。 This can be caused by any number of things from heavy rainfall to heavy buildings to the absence of sufficient deep－rooted vegetation to hold the layers together。 Here we see a steep cliff without a tree in sight。 The slightest pressure on it will cause a landslide、 which、 with a little help from your imagination、 you will be able to see happening in this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/圧 あつ">アツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>153<br><h1> 埼 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埼%20%23kanji">Cape</a></h1>The cape pictured here is a jut of land like Cape Cod。 The soil on the left tells us we have to do with land、 and the strange on the right tells us it is a cape where unusual things go on。 Put a haunted house on it、 an eerie sky overhead、 and a howling wind rustling through the trees、 and you have yourself a picture of Cape Strange （or、 if you prefer、 Cape Odd）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埼 さい">さい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>154<br><h1> 垣 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/垣%20%23kanji">Hedge</a></h1>The hedge depicted in this frame is not your ordinary run－ofthe－suburbs shrubbery、 but the miraculous hedge of briar roses that completely spanned the castle grounds in which Sleeping Beauty lay for a hundred years、 so that none but her predestined beloved could find his way through it。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/垣 かき">かき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>155<br><h1> 圭 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/圭%20%23kanji">Squared jewel</a></h1>Now I am going to do something unusual。 The character in this frame is going to get one meaning and the primitive another、 with no relation at all between the two。 In time、 I hope you will see how helpful this is。 The kanji key word、 squared jewel、 depicts a mammoth precious stone、 several feet high、 made by piling up large heaps of soil on top of one another。 Not something you would want to present your betrothed on your wedding day、 but a good image for remembering this rare character、 used chiefly in personal names nowadays。  As a primitive、 we shall use this character to mean ivy、 that creepy vegetation that covers the surface of the ground to form a sort of “second” ground that can get somewhat tricky to walk on without tripping。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>156<br><h1> 封 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/封%20%23kanji">Seal</a></h1>Think of the key word seal as referring to a letter you have written and are preparing to close。 Instead of using the traditional wax seal、 you glue a sprig of ivy on the outside。 In this way the elements ivy and glue give you a curious and memorable way to seal your secret letters。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/封 ふう">フウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/封 ほう">ホウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>157<br><h1> 涯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/涯%20%23kanji">Horizon</a></h1>After seeing a constant horizon of water、 water everywhere for months at sea、 could there be anything more delightful to the eyes than to look astern and see the ivy－clad cliff s of land on a new horizon？ Of course、 you’d need the eyes of a stellar telescope to recognize that the vegetation was in fact ivy、 but the phrase “ivy－clad cliff s” has such a nice ring to it that we won’t worry about such details。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/涯 がい">ガイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
