<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>158<br><h1> 寺 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寺%20%23kanji">Buddhist temple</a></h1>You have heard of people “attaching” themselves to a particular sect？ Here is your chance to take that metaphor literally and imagine some fellow walking into a Buddhist temple with a fervent resolve to attach himself to the place。 Since there is plenty of unused land around the precincts、 he simply picks out a suitable patch、 brushes the soles of his feet with glue、 steps down firmly、 and so joins the Buddhist temple as a “permanent member。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寺 じ">ジ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寺 てら">てら</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>159<br><h1> 時 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/時%20%23kanji">Time</a></h1>“What is time？” asked St。 Augustine in his memoirs。 “Ask me not、 and I know。 Ask me、 and I cannot tell you。” Here we have the kanji’s answer to that perennial riddle。 Time is a sun rising over a Buddhist temple。 It sounds almost like a Zen kōan whose repetition might yield some deep secret to the initiated。 At any rate、 imagining a monk seated in meditation pondering it might help us remember the character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/時 じ">ジ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/時 とき">とき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>160<br><h1> 均 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/均%20%23kanji">Level</a></h1>The level this key word refers to is not the carpenter’s tool but rather the even surface of a thing。 It pictures soil being scooped up into a ladle and then made level （apparently because one is measuring soil）。 The excess drops of soil are brushed off the top、 which accounts for the added drop at the ladle’s edge。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/均 きん">キン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>161<br><h1> 火 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火%20%23kanji">Fire</a></h1>Just as sitting before a fire enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames、 this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of fire you want to see。 It no longer makes a good pictograph、 but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form—first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there—to see what you can come up with。 Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here。 No doubt you、 too、 will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes。  To avoid confusion later on、it is best to keep to the meaning of a fireplace （or hearth） or a raging conflagration like a forest fire for this kanji’s primitive meaning。 Another primitive element for fire、 based on this one、 is written 灬 and will mean flames、 cauldron、 cooking fire、 or an oven fire。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 ひ">ひ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/火 ほ">ほ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>162<br><h1> 炎 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎%20%23kanji">Inflammation</a></h1>A fire belongs in the hearth、 not over it。 When the fire spreads to the rest of the house、 we have an inflamed house。 And as with any inflammation—including those that attack our bodies—the danger is always that it might spread if not checked。 This is the sense behind the reduplication of the element for fire、 one atop the other<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎 えん">エン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/炎 ほのお">ほのお</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>163<br><h1> 煩 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩%20%23kanji">Anxiety</a></h1>The existential condition of anxiety that arises from the inevitable frustration of our worldly passions is contained in this character。 The head is set afire、 causing deep torment of spirit （and a whopper of a headache）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩 はん">ハン</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩 ぼん">ボン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩わずらう">わずら－う</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/煩わずらわす">わずら－わす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>164<br><h1> 淡 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡%20%23kanji">Thin</a></h1>The primitives in this kanji read： water 。 。 。 inflammation。 Taking inflammation in its medical sense、 the first water－related inflammation that pops into mind is dehydration、 the principal symptom of which is that it makes one shrivel up and look very、 very thin。 If that is hard to remember、 try thinking it backwards： a very thin chap passes by and you imagine him suffering from （being inflamed with） dehydration （hence the element for water）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡 たん">タン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/淡あわい">あわ－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>165<br><h1> 灯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯%20%23kanji">Lamp</a></h1>Since it is very hard to read by the fireplace without going blind from the flickering of the flames or burning up from the heat、 our ancestors invented a way to nail down a bit of that fire、 just enough to light up the text of their evening newspapers and no more。 Voilà！ The lamp。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灯 ひ">ひ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>166<br><h1> 畑 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑%20%23kanji">Farm</a></h1>Looking at the primitives、 a fireplace and a rice field、 we find the essential ingredients for a farm： a warm hearth to sit by at night、 and a well－plowed field to grow one’s crops in by day。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑 はた">はた</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畑 はたけ">はたけ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>167<br><h1> 災 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災%20%23kanji">Disaster</a></h1>Of all of nature’s disasters、 this kanji picks out two of the worst： floods and fires。 To recall the disposition of the elements、 think of nature’s solution to nature’s own problem： a great flood pouring down over a great forest fire。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/災わざわい">わざわ－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>168<br><h1> 灰 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灰%20%23kanji">Ashes</a></h1>The kanji for ashes naturally includes the primitive for fire、 or more specifically、 a fireplace。 Now what do you do with that bucket of ashes you have just cleaned out of the fireplace？ You walk to the edge of a cliff and tip it upside down、 watching as they are swept away in the wind like a swarm of gray mosquitoes。 Thus the fire、 once it has turned to ashes、 ends up at the bottom of the cliff。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灰 かい">カイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/灰 はい">はい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>169<br><h1> 点 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点%20%23kanji">Spot</a></h1>If you look into the flickering of a fire for a long time and then turn aside、 you will see spots before your eyes。 Although nobody ever thought of such a thing before—as least as far as I know、 they didn’t—imagine using those spots as a technique for fortune－telling。 The old witch sits before her cauldron and watches the spots that show up when she turns to look at you、 and from that tells your fortune。 Think of it as a kind of spot－check on your future。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/点 てん">テン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>170<br><h1> 照 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/照%20%23kanji">Illuminate</a></h1>Although the range of possible meanings that the kanji for illuminate can have is about as rich as the connotations of the English word、 we need to focus on just one of them： to make something shine。 If you glaze a pot and put it into the oven to fire it、 you in fact illuminate it。 Hence the kanji for illuminate compares the kanji for shining with the primitive element for the oven’s fire。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/照 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/照てる">て－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/照てらす">て－らす</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/照てれる">て－れる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>171<br><h1> 魚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/魚%20%23kanji">Fish</a></h1>The composition of this kanji shows three elements、 which we list in the order of their writing： bound up 。 。 。 rice field 。 。 。 cooking fire。 Not much to work with at first sight。 But we can join them together by thinking of a three－part story： first a fish is caught and bound up on a line with its unfortunate school－mates； when the fisherman gets home、 he cuts off the head and tosses it、 with the entrails、 out into the rice fields for fertilizer； and the rest he sets in a skillet over a cooking fire for his supper。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/魚 ぎょ">ギョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/魚 うお">うお</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/魚 さかな">さかな</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>172<br><h1> 漁 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁%20%23kanji">Fishing</a></h1>To the story we have just made about fish、 this kanji for the profession of fishing adds yet another element before the others： namely the water、 where the fish was happily at home before being caught、 disemboweled、 and eaten。 Be sure to get a clear image of the water when you put it all together。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁 ぎょ">ギョ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漁 りょう">リョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>173<br><h1> 里 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里%20%23kanji">Ri</a></h1>That’s right—a ri。 Don’t bother looking it up in your English dictionary； it’s a Japanese word for measuring distances。 One ri is about 4 kilometers or 2。5 miles。 The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used。 Atop we see the rice field、 and below the element for land。 Those four sections you see in the rice field （and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14 田） are actually measurements of land、 much the same as farm－sections in the United States have given us the notion of a “country mile。” The land division based on the size of a rice field is called a ri。  To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this kanji、we shall refer to it as a computer、 a meaning deriving from the kanji for logic、 which we will meet in Lesson 12。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里 り">リ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/里 さと">さと</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>174<br><h1> 黒 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒%20%23kanji">Black</a></h1>Like most things electrical、 a computer、 too、 can overheat。 Just imagine flames pouring out of it and charring the keyboard、 the monitor、 and your desk a sooty black color。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒 こく">コク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒 くろ">くろ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/黒くろい">くろ－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>175<br><h1> 墨 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨%20%23kanji">Black ink</a></h1>Besides meaning black ink、 this kanji also appears in the word for an inked string that is pulled taut and snapped to mark a surface、 much the same as one might used a chalked string。 Here it is used to mark off the dirt with black lines for a football game （played、 I presume、 on a white field）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨 ぼく">ボク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墨 すみ">すみ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>176<br><h1> 鯉 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鯉%20%23kanji">Carp</a></h1>These are the same carp you see in Japanese “carp streamers。” Only here we find a small home computer or two strung on the line by a father anxious for his son not only to have the courage and determination of a carp swimming upstream、 but also the efficiency and memory of a computer。 Ugh。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>177<br><h1> 量 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量%20%23kanji">Quantity</a></h1>Think of quantity as having to do with measuring time and distance、 and the rest is simple： you have a quantity of time in the new day that begins with nightbreak、 and a quantity of distance in the rural ri。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量 りょう">リョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/量はかる">はか－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>178<br><h1> 厘 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘%20%23kanji">Rin</a></h1>No doubt you will find it in your heart to forgive me for forcing yet another Japanese word on you in this frame。 It is not the last time it will happen in this book、 but I can assure you they are used only when absolutely necessary。 One rin is equal to about 1／1000 of a yen—or rather was worth that much when it still made economic sense to mint them。 While inflation took its toll on this kanji as a monetary unit、 it survived with the not at all surprising sense of something “very、 very tiny。” The kanji shows a cliff with a computer under it、 apparently because it has been pushed over into the abyss by someone fed up with the thing。 The total market value of one home computer that has fallen over rock and bramble for several hundred feet： about one rin！<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/厘 りん">リン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>179<br><h1> 埋 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋%20%23kanji">Bury</a></h1>When we speak of burying something （or someone、 for that matter）、 we usually mean putting them under ground。 Only here、 we are burying our beloved computer that has served us so well these past years。 Behind us a choir chants the “Dies irae、 dies illa” and there is much wailing and grief among the bystanders as they pass by to shovel a little dirt into what will be its final resting place。 R。I。P。 Before going any further、 we might pause a moment to look at precisely where the primitive elements were placed in the kanji of the last frame： the ground to the left and the computer to the right。 Neither of these is an absolutely fixed position。 The kanji for spit （frame 151 吐）、 for instance、 puts ground on the right、 and that for plains （frame 1596 野） will put the computer on the left 。 While there is no reason to bother memorizing any “rules、” a quick glance through a few general guidelines may help。 Use them if they help； if not、 simply adjust the story for a problem character in such a way as to help you remember the position of the elements relative to one another。 In any case、 here are the guidelines that follow from the kanji treated up to this point：<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋 まい">マイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋うめる">う－める</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋うまる">う－まる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/埋うもれる">う－もれる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>180<br><h1> 同 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同%20%23kanji">Same</a></h1>The primitives given are one and mouth under a hood。 Take the key word to connote the sameness that characterizes the life in a community of monks。 They all have the same habits、 including the “habit” they wear on their backs。 Here we see the monk’s cowl、 drawn down over the eyes so that all you can see when you look at him is a mouth。 But since monks also speak their prayers in common、 it is but a short step to think of one mouth under a hood as the kanji for the sameness of monastic life。  As a primitive、 this kanji will mean monks dressed in a common habit。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同 どう">ドウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/同おなじ">おな－じ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>181<br><h1> 洞 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞%20%23kanji">Den</a></h1>The key word den refers to an animal lair hollowed out in the side of a mountain。 Now if we keep to the image of the monas－ tic life as an image for same、 we can picture a den of wild beasts dressed up in habits and living the common life in a mountain cavern。 To bring in the element of water we need only give them a sacred “puddle” in the center of their den、 the focus of all their pious attentions。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞 どう">ドウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洞 ほら">ほら</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>182<br><h1> 胴 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴%20%23kanji">Trunk</a></h1>The word trunk refers to the part of the body that is left when you have “truncated” all the limbs。 I can hardly think of any reason for doing so、 unless one were lumberjacking corpses and needed to have them all properly pruned and made the same so they could be floated downstream without causing a body－jam。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/胴 どう">ドウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>183<br><h1> 向 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向%20%23kanji">Yonder</a></h1>Something referred to as “over yonder” is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight—like a wee drop in the distance—and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out。 Hence this kanji begins with a drop。 Then we find a sort of transparent helmet with no eyes or nose、 but only a prominent mouth under it、 obviously an extraterrestrial。 And what is it jabbering on about with its mouth open like that？ Why、 about his spaceship way over yonder with its fuel tank on empty。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向むく">む－く</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向むける">む－ける</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向むかう">む－かう</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/向むこう">む－こう</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>184<br><h1> 尚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/尚%20%23kanji">Esteem</a></h1>Above we see the primitive for little attached to one of those glass canopies you might use to display a family heirloom。 The littleness is important、 because what is in fact on display is the shrunken、 stuff ed、 and mounted mouth of an esteemed ancestor。 We may be used to esteeming the words our forebears leave behind、 but here we also esteem the very mouth that spoke them。 I leave it to you to imagine a suitable place in your room for displaying such an unusual conversation piece。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/尚 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>185<br><h1> 字 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字%20%23kanji">Character</a></h1>Here is the character for character itself。 Not just kanji、 but any written character from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet。 It shows us simply a child in a house。 But let us take advantage of the double meaning of the key word to note that just as a child born to a Japanese house is given characters for its name、 so it is also stamped with the character of those who raise it from infancy on。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字 じ">ジ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/字 あざ">あざ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>186<br><h1> 守 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/守%20%23kanji">Guard</a></h1>The notion of guarding something easily brings to mind the image of someone standing guard、 like the royal soldiers in front of Buckingham Palace or the Pope’s Swiss Guard。 The whole idea of hiring guards is that they should stick like glue to your house to protect it from unwanted prowlers。 So go ahead and glue a guard to your house in imagination。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/守 しゅ">シュ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/守 す">ス</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/守まもる">まも－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/守もり">も－り</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>187<br><h1> 完 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/完%20%23kanji">Perfect</a></h1>In order not to confuse the key word perfect with others nearly synonymous in meaning、 pull it apart to have a look at its native Latin roots。 Per－factum suggests something so “thoroughly made or done” that nothing more needs to be added to it。 Now look at the kanji、 which does something similar。 We see a house that has been made perfectly from its beginnings in the foundation to the roof on the top。 Now return to frame 97　「了」　 and make sure not to confuse this key word with the kanji for complete。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/完 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>188<br><h1> 宣 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宣%20%23kanji">Proclaim</a></h1>Under the primitive for house we meet the kanji for span。 Think of the key word in its religious sense of missionary preaching： “proclaiming the good news to all nations” and “shouting it from the housetops。” That should be enough to help you remember this simple kanji、 used in fact both for traditional missionary work as well as for one of its contemporary replacements： advertising。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宣 せん">セン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>189<br><h1> 宵 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵%20%23kanji">Wee hours</a></h1>As the key word hints、 the kanji in this frame refers to the late evening or early morning hours、 well after one should be in bed asleep。 It does this by picturing a house with a candle in it。 The reason is obvious： whoever is living there is “burning the candle at both ends、” and working night after night into the wee hours。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宵 よい">よい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>190<br><h1> 安 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安%20%23kanji">Relax</a></h1>To be told that the place of the woman is in the house may not sit well with modern thought、 but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age。 So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of relaxing after a hard day’s work： the scruff y and weary woman of the house slouched asleep in the living room chair、 her hair in curlers and a duster lying in her lap。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安 あん">アン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/安やすい">やす－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>191<br><h1> 宴 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴%20%23kanji">Banquet</a></h1>To carry on from the last frame、 we note the entire day of work that comes between a woman and her house in preparing for a dinner banquet、 pictorially “interrupting” her relaxation。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/宴 えん">エン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>192<br><h1> 寄 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄%20%23kanji">Draw near</a></h1>Let the idea of drawing near suggest something dangerous or eerie that one approaches with fear and trembling。 Here we see a strange house—perhaps the haunted House of Usher that Edgar Allen Poe immortalized、 or the enchanted Gingerbread House that lured Hansel and Gretel to draw near。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄 き">キ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄よる">よ－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寄よせる">よ－せる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>193<br><h1> 富 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富%20%23kanji">Wealth</a></h1>Here we have the original character on which the primitive element for wealth is based。 In keeping with the story introduced back then、 note how all the wealth is kept under the roof of the same house。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 ふ">フ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 ふう">フウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富とむ">と－む</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/富 とみ">とみ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>194<br><h1> 貯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯%20%23kanji">Savings</a></h1>To avoid confusing this frame with the last one、 try to think of savings as actual money。 The only diff erence is that our currency is not paper bills but shells、 a not uncommon unit of exchange in older civilizations。 The nail under the roof of the house points to a hiding place in the raft ers on which one strings up one’s shells for safekeeping。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/貯 ちょ">チョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>195<br><h1> 木 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木%20%23kanji">Tree</a></h1>Here we see a pictograph of a tree、 showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke。 The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots。 Although it may look similar at first sight to the kanji for water （frame 130 水）、 the order in which it is written is completely diff erent and this aff ects its final appearance。  As a primitive、 this kanji can mean tree or wood。 When the last two strokes are detached from the trunk （膈）、 we shall change its meaning to pole、 or wooden pole。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 ぼく">ボク</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 もく">モク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 き">き</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/木 こ">こ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>196<br><h1> 林 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林%20%23kanji">Grove</a></h1>Learn this frame in connection with the next one。 A grove is a small cluster of trees。 Hence the simple reduplication of the kanji for tree gives us the grove。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林 りん">リン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/林 はやし">はやし</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>197<br><h1> 森 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森%20%23kanji">Forest</a></h1>A forest is a large expanse of trees、 or “trees、 trees everywhere、” to adopt the expression we used back in frames 22 and 23。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森 しん">シン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/森 もり">もり</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>198<br><h1> 桂 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/桂%20%23kanji">Japanese Judas－tree</a></h1>Unless you are a botanist、 you are not likely to know what a Japanese Judas－tree looks like、 and probably never even heard of it before、 but the name is sufficiently odd to make remembering it easy。 Using the primitives as our guide、 we define it as a tree with ivy growing down its branches in the shape of a hangman’s rope。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>199<br><h1> 柏 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柏%20%23kanji">Oak</a></h1>This kanji calls to mind the famous myth of the “golden bough。” As you may recall、 what made the sacred oak in the forest of Diana the Huntress outside of Rome “golden” were the white berries of the mistletoe that grew in the branches of the tree。 When the light of the sun shone through them、 they turned yellow and the branch to which they clung appeared to be made of gold。 （If you don’t know the story、 take a break today and hunt it down in a dictionary of myth and fable。 Even if you forget the kanji—which、 of course、 you won’t—the story of the mistletoe and the fate it brought to Balder the Beautiful is one you are sure to remember。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>200<br><h1> 枠 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枠%20%23kanji">Frame</a></h1>You might think of the frame this character refers to as the sort of frame we have created by drawing a dark line around this kanji and its explanation。 Then think of that line as made of very thin wood； and finally note how each time the line bends it forms a 90° angle、 thus giving us the nine and the ten。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枠 わく">わく</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>201<br><h1> 梢 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/梢%20%23kanji">Treetops</a></h1>As the days grow shorter and shorter、 or so the northern European myth goes、 the fear grows that the sun will take its leave of us altogether、 abandoning the world to total darkness。 Fixing candles to the branches of evergreen trees、 it was believed、 would lure the sun back （like things attracting like things）、 whence the custom of the lighted tree that eventually found its way into our Christmas customs。 The story is a lot longer and more complex than that、 but it should help to fix the image of climb ing high up into the treetops to fix candles on the tree。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>202<br><h1> 棚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/棚%20%23kanji">Shelf</a></h1>One often thinks of books as “good companions、” but here it is the shelf we store them on that is the companion。 The reasons should be obvious： it is made of the same stuff 、 wood、 and spends a lot more time with them than we do！ Here again、 be careful not to let the rationality of the explanation get in the way before you turn it into a proper story。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/棚 たな">たな</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>203<br><h1> 杏 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杏%20%23kanji">Apricot</a></h1>Since apricots can be eaten just as they fall from the trees、 picture this mouth agape at the bottom of a tree （just as the elements have it）、 waiting for apricots to fall into it。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>204<br><h1> 桐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/桐%20%23kanji">Paulownia</a></h1>Since you probably don’t know what a paulownia tree is、 we shall let the key word suggest the phrase “the Little Brothers of St。 Paulownia。” It is a short step to associate the tree with the monks to its right。 （For the curious、 the name of this oriental tree really comes from a Russian princess、 Anna Pavlovna。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>205<br><h1> 植 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/植%20%23kanji">Plant</a></h1>You have no doubt seen how people practicing the Japanese art of bonsai take those helpless little saplings and twist them into crippled dwarves before they have a chance to grow up as they should。 The more proper way to plant a young tree and give it a fair shake in life is to set it into the earth in such a way that it can grow up straight。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/植 しょく">ショク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/植うえる">う－える</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/植うわる">う－わる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>206<br><h1> 枯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枯%20%23kanji">Wither</a></h1>What makes a tree begin to wither up、 and perhaps even die、 is a kind of arteriosclerosis that keeps its sap from flowing freely。 Usually this is due to simple old age、 as this character shows us。 Be sure to picture a wrinkled old tree、 withering away in a retirement center so that the commonsense explanation does not take over。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枯 こ">コ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枯かれる">か－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/枯からす">か－らす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>207<br><h1> 朴 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朴%20%23kanji">Crude</a></h1>As all magicians who have passed their apprenticeship know、 one makes one’s wand out of a hazel branch and is careful not to alter the natural form of the wood。 For the magic of the wand derives its power from its association with the hidden laws of nature、 and needs therefore to be kept in its crude、 natural state。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朴 ぼく">ボク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>208<br><h1> 村 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村%20%23kanji">Town</a></h1>The character for village was associated with rice fields （frame 92 町）。 That for town、 a step up on the evolutionary path to cities、 shows a circle of trees glued together to measure off the confines of a town。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村 そん">ソン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/村 むら">むら</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>209<br><h1> 相 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/相%20%23kanji">Inter</a></h1>The prefix inter－ stirs up associations of cooperation among people。 From there we read off the elements： tree 。 。 。 eye。 With only a slight leap of the imagination、 those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one’s own eye before helping your neighbors remove the splinters in their eyes。 What more useful rule for interhuman relationships、 and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji！<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/相 そう">ソウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/相 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/相 あい">あい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>210<br><h1> 机 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/机%20%23kanji">Desk</a></h1>We need to fix imagination here on two things to learn the kanji for desk： the wonderful rough wood of which it has been hewn and the wind that blows across it、 sending your papers flying all over the room。 These two elements、 written in that order、 dictate how to write the character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/机 き">キ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/机 つくえ">つくえ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>211<br><h1> 本 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/本%20%23kanji">Book</a></h1>Recalling that books are made of paper、 and paper made of trees、 one might think of a book as a slice of a tree。 Can you see the “cross－cut” in the trunk of the tree？ Picture it as a chain－saw cutting you out a few books with which to start your own private library。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/本 ほん">ホン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/本 もと">もと</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>212<br><h1> 札 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/札%20%23kanji">Tag</a></h1>The tags you see hanging on trees in public places in Japan are helpful to identify what sort of trees they are。 Next time you see one、 imagine the bit of wire that fixes the tag to the branch as a large fishhook。 really imagine it、 illogical as it is、 and you will never have trouble with this kanji again。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/札 さつ">サツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/札 ふだ">ふだ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>213<br><h1> 暦 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暦%20%23kanji">Calendar</a></h1>Look at this character in reverse order、 from bottom up。 First we see the primitive for days、 an appropriate enough way to begin a calendar。 Next we see a grove of trees growing under a cliff。 The laws of nature being what they are、 the trees would be stunted under such conditions、 unless they were strong enough to keep growing upwards until they passed through the layers of rock and soil、 right up to the surface。 Now imagine that in those little boxes marking off the days on your wall calendar、 you see that very process taking place step by step： 365 or so time－lapse pictures of that grove of trees each month、 from January under the cliff to December on top of the cliff。 The story is not as complex as it sounds、 particularly if you happen to have a calendar nearby and can flip through it with this image in mind。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暦 れき">レキ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暦 こよみ">こよみ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>214<br><h1> 案 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/案%20%23kanji">Plan</a></h1>Without much eff ort、 the elements relax 。 。 。 tree suggest a hammock strung between two trees in your backyard、 and you stretched out in it、 hands folded behind your head、 planning something or other。 After all、 it’s something we all do from time to time： kick up our legs on the nearest piece of furniture and daydream about the best plan of action to take。 Be sure to relate the relaxation to the tree、 so that you don’t end up with something else in its place （like “legs” or “desk” or “table”）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/案 あん">アン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>215<br><h1> 燥 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/燥%20%23kanji">Parch</a></h1>Parchment、 made from animal skins、 was the most common form of writing material used until the beginning of the nineteenth century。 When paper took over、 a method was devised to make artificial parchment from wood pulp。 The fire at the left and in the “strong” position reminds us of the root word、 “parch、” since nothing dries、 puckers、 wrinkles、 and scorches quite like fire。 And here is how we put it all together。 Take a sheet of paper （a “wood－good、”）、 wet it、 and hold it over a hearth in your mind’s eye。 Now watch as it parches the paper、 leaving it with a strange and bumpy surface resembling parchment。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/燥 そう">ソウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>216<br><h1> 未 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/未%20%23kanji">Not yet</a></h1>As the key word suggests、 this kanji has to do with something not quite over and done with。 More concretely、 it shows us a tree that is not yet fully grown。 The extra short stroke in the upper branches shows new branches spreading out、 leaving one with the feeling that the tree has a ways to go yet before it reaches maturity。 In other words、 the kanji conveys its mean ing pictographically、 playing on the earlier pictograph of the tree。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/未 み">ミ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>217<br><h1> 末 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/末%20%23kanji">Extremity</a></h1>This character is best learned in connection with that of the previous frame。 The first stroke shows a branch that is longer than the main branch、 indicating that the tree has reached the extremity of its growth、 so that its branches stop spreading and start drooping downwards。 Be sure to keep this imagery in mind、 to avoid confusing this key word with synonyms that will appear later。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/末 まつ">マツ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/末 ばつ">バツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/末 すえ">すえ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>218<br><h1> 沫 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沫%20%23kanji">Splash</a></h1>The splash this kanji refers to is the dash of water against the rocks、 with all the foam and spray that this creates。 If you think of a splash in this sense as a wave that has run its full course and reached its extremity、 namely the seashore、 and if you think of it pictorially in your mind’s eye、 this somewhat rare （but oh－soeasy－to－learn） kanji is yours for good。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>219<br><h1> 味 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/味%20%23kanji">Flavor</a></h1>When a tree has not yet finished growing、 it produces fruit with a full flavor。 When the official taster （the professional mouth to the left ） determines that full flavor has been reached、 the tree is pruned back so that it remains permanently not yet grown。 A neat little agricultural trick and an easy way to see the sense of flavor hidden in this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/味 み">ミ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/味 あじ">あじ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/味あじわう">あじ－わう</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>220<br><h1> 妹 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妹%20%23kanji">Youngersister</a></h1>The younger sister in the family is the woman in the family who、 like the newest branch in a tree、 is not yet old enough or mature enough to do everything the elder sister can do （see frame 413 姉）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妹 まい">マイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妹 いもうと">いもうと</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>221<br><h1> 朱 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朱%20%23kanji">Vermilion</a></h1>That red－orange color we call vermilion is found in nature during the fall when the leaves lose their sugar and begin to change color。 This kanji depicts the very last leaf on a tree in the fall （the drop hung in the first stroke）、 the leaf that has not yet fallen as it one day must。 Look at its color—vermilion。 （Well、 not really。 The truth is、 vermilion is made from a mercuric sulfide、 but I’m sure you will agree that autumn leaves are a lot easier to work with。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/朱 しゅ">シュ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>222<br><h1> 株 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/株%20%23kanji">Stocks</a></h1>The stocks bought and sold on the market by the tens of millions each day get their name from a comparison to a healthy tree、 in which one takes “stock” in the hopes that it will grow and produce more and more trees like itself。 Usually good stocks are referred to as “blue chip、” but here we are asked to associate the key word with the color vermilion、 perhaps because one can assess the value of a tree from the color of its autumn leaves。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/株 かぶ">かぶ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>223<br><h1> 若 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/若%20%23kanji">Young</a></h1>Here we see a flower held in the right hand。 You can imagine yourself in a magic garden where flowers picked with the right hand grant eternal youth； and those picked with the left 、 premature senility。 Go ahead、 pick one with each hand and watch what happens。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/若 じゃく">ジャク</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/若 にゃく">ニャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/若わかい">わか－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/若もしくは">も－しくは</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>224<br><h1> 草 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/草%20%23kanji">Grass</a></h1>Perhaps you know the custom of seeding grass randomly or in some particular pattern with the flower called the crocus、 which blooms for a few days each year in early spring。 As the grass begins to turn green again after winter has passed、 these tiny flowers dot up here and there。 Now just look out your window at a patch of grass somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in flowers once as a sort of early harbinger of spring。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/草 そう">ソウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/草 くさ">くさ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>225<br><h1> 苦 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦%20%23kanji">Suffering</a></h1>The picture of suffering we are given here is that of a flower that has grown old。 When a flower ages、 it pales and dries up、 and probably even suff ers。 If you think that plants are incapable of such feelings、 then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flowers helps them bloom better。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦 く">ク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦くるしい">くる－しい</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦くるしむ">くる－しむ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦くるしめる">くる－しめる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦にがい">にが－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苦にがる">にが－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>226<br><h1> 寛 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寛%20%23kanji">Tolerant</a></h1>The house of flowers or “hothouse” has become a metaphor for a narrow－minded、 biased、 and intolerant attitude distrustful of change。 Tolerance、 in contrast、 is open－minded and welcomes novelty。 The way to encourage tolerance in those who lack it is first to have them see through their own hothouse attitudes、 which is the very counsel we are given in this kanji。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寛 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>227<br><h1> 薄 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄%20%23kanji">Dilute</a></h1>Take a good look at this kanji： the “strong” element here is really the flower、 not the water as you might have thought on first glance。 To the right is the acupuncturist from frame 47 博。 Taking the key word to connote diluting the vital humors of the body、 we can imagine our acupuncturist performing his task with flowers in place of needles、 and using their hollow stems to pipe water into the body of the patient。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄 はく">ハク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄うすい">うす－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄うすめる">うす－める</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄うすまる">うす－まる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄うすらぐ">うす－らぐ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薄うすれる">うす－れる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>228<br><h1> 葉 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/葉%20%23kanji">Leaf</a></h1>Three elements are given here： flower 。 。 。 generation 。 。 。 tree。 The first and last seem logical enough、 since it is the leaf that feeds the flowers on a tree。 The element for generation interposed between the two suggests that the movement of a tree from one generation to the next is like its “turning over a new leaf。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/葉 よう">ヨウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/葉 は">は</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>229<br><h1> 模 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/模%20%23kanji">Imitation</a></h1>Ah、 but haven’t modern graveyards become a parody of their ancestors！ The flowers are plastic、 the writing on the stones is unimaginative and cold、 and the whole thing looks more like a marble orchard than a right and proper graveyard。 This kanji continues with the modernization trend by picturing imitation trees in the graveyard。 But of course、 how convenient！ They don’t need pruning or fertilizing、 their leaves don’t fall、 and they remain the same color all year long。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/模 も">モ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/模 ぼ">ボ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>230<br><h1> 漠 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漠%20%23kanji">Vague</a></h1>Think of the key word as having to do with something viewed through a haze、 or in the twilight and from a distance、 so that only its outlines are vaguely discernible。 Now we are back again to the essence of the true graveyard。 The water may be taken as the sound of waves dashing up against the rocks or the dripping of moisture on cold rock—anything that helps you associate vagueness with the graveyard and keep it distinct from the imitation we met in the last frame。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漠 ばく">バク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>231<br><h1> 墓 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墓%20%23kanji">Grave</a></h1>The mounds of soil with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those boot－hill graves we all know from cowboy lore。 The only odd thing about this kanji is that the soil comes under the graveyard、 rather than to its left 、 where we might expect。 Just think of the bodies as “lying under boot－hill” if you have any trouble。 By the way、 this is not the first time、 nor will it be the last、 that we learn a kanji whose key word is the same、 or almost the same、 as a primitive element based on it、 but whose shape differs somewhat。 There is no cause to worry。 By using the primitive in a variety of other characters、 as we have done here、 the confusion will be averted as a matter of course。 In most cases、 as here、 the primitive element is taken from a part of the fuller kanji。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墓 ぼ">ボ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/墓 はか">はか</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>232<br><h1> 暮 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暮%20%23kanji">Livelihood</a></h1>Imagine that you have chosen the occupation of the keeper of a graveyard and spend your days tending to other’s deadhood in order to make your means of livelihood。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暮 ぼ">ボ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暮くれる">く－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暮くらす">く－らす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>233<br><h1> 膜 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/膜%20%23kanji">Membrane</a></h1>The part of the body first aff ected by a stroll through a haunted graveyard is the skin、 which gets goose bumps。 But we save the word “skin” for another kanji、 and use the odd word “membrane” here。 Think of being so scared through and through that the goose flesh moves from the outside in、 giving you goose membranes。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/膜 まく">マク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>234<br><h1> 苗 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苗%20%23kanji">Seedling</a></h1>To avoid confusion with the image of rice seedlings to appear later、 we shall take these seedlings out of their agricultural setting in the rice fields and into the frame of Brave New World surgery、 where “ideas” or “values” are being implanted into brains like seedlings to insure a harmonious society。 Then you need only imagine them taking root and breaking out into flower right through the tops of the skulls of people walking around on the streets。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苗 びょう">ビョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苗 なえ">なえ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/苗 なわ">なわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>235<br><h1> 兆 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兆%20%23kanji">Portent</a></h1>Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle、 the two sloping vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern。 Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future、 and in particular things that portend coming evils。  When this character is used as a primitive in its full form、 we keep the key－word sense of a portent。 When it appears to the left in its abbreviated form （namely、 the left half only、 丬）、 we shall give it the pictographic sense of a turtle。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兆 ちょう">チョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兆きざす">きざ－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兆きざし">きざ－し</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>236<br><h1> 桃 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/桃%20%23kanji">Peach tree</a></h1>To associate the peach tree with the primitive for a portent、 recall the famous Japanese legend of Momotarō、 the Peach Boy。 It begins once upon a time with a fisherman and his wife who wanted badly to have a child、 but none was born to them。 Then one day the old man caught a giant peach、 out of which jumped a healthy young lad whom they named Peach Boy。 Though the boy was destined to perform heroic deeds、 his birth also portended great misfortune （how else could he become a hero？）。 Thus the tree that is associated with a portent of coming evil comes to be the peach tree。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/桃 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/桃 もも">もも</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>237<br><h1> 眺 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/眺%20%23kanji">Stare</a></h1>To give someone the “evil eye” is to stare at them、 wishing them evil。 The roots of the superstition are old and almost universal throughout the cultures of the world。 In this kanji、 too、 being stared at is depicted as an eye that portends evil。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/眺 ちょう">チョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/眺ながめる">なが－める</a></div>
