<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>537<br><h1> 滝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/滝%20%23kanji">Waterfall</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 vase 。 。 。 eels。 To avoid the confusion mentioned in the previous frame、 the character learned there for dragon should not be used as a primitive。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/滝 たき">たき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>538<br><h1> 豚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豚%20%23kanji">Pork</a></h1>Flesh 。 。 。 sow。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豚 とん">トン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豚 ぶた">ぶた</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>539<br><h1> 逐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逐%20%23kanji">Pursue</a></h1>Sows 。 。 。 road。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/逐 ちく">チク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>540<br><h1> 遂 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/遂%20%23kanji">Consummate</a></h1>The horns atop the sow suggest a boar at work in the background。 Add the element for a road。 Now create a story whose meaning is： consummate。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/遂 すい">スイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/遂とげる">と－げる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>541<br><h1> 家 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/家%20%23kanji">House</a></h1>This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already。 To help a little、 this kanji recalls the times when the “domestic” animals were、 as the word itself suggests、 really kept in the house。 Hence： house 。 。 。 sow。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/家 か">カ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/家 け">ケ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/家 いえ">いえ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/家 や">や</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>542<br><h1> 嫁 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫁%20%23kanji">Marry into</a></h1>The kanji in this frame demonstrates the traditional Japanese approach to marriage： it is the woman who leaves her family for another household、 thus marrying into a man’s family。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫁 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫁 よめ">よめ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫁とつぐ">とつ－ぐ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>543<br><h1> 豪 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豪%20%23kanji">Overpowering</a></h1>Tall 。 。 。 crowned 。 。 。 sow。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豪 ごう">ゴウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>544<br><h1> 腸 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腸%20%23kanji">Intestines</a></h1>Flesh 。 。 。 piggy bank。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腸 ちょう">チョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>545<br><h1> 場 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/場%20%23kanji">Location</a></h1>Soil 。 。 。 piggy bank。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/場 じょう">ジョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/場 ば">ば</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>546<br><h1> 湯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/湯%20%23kanji">Hot water</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 piggy bank。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/湯 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/湯 ゆ">ゆ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>547<br><h1> 羊 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羊%20%23kanji">Sheep</a></h1>This pictograph shows the animal horns at the top attached to the head （3rd stroke）、 the front and back legs （strokes 4 and 5） and body （final stroke）。  The primitive meaning of sheep can add the further connotations given in the following frame。As we saw with the cow、 the “tail” is cut off when it is set immediately over another element： 胝。 Note the change in stroke order、 as exemplified in the following frame。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羊 よう">ヨウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羊 ひつじ">ひつじ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>548<br><h1> 美 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/美%20%23kanji">Beauty</a></h1>Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of beauty with a large sheep。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/美 び">ビ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/美うつくしい">うつく－しい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>549<br><h1> 洋 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洋%20%23kanji">Ocean</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 sheep。 Be sure to keep the stories and key word of this kanji distinct from those for sea。 （frame 461 海）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/洋 よう">ヨウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>550<br><h1> 詳 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詳%20%23kanji">Detailed</a></h1>Words／speaking 。 。 。 sheep。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詳 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詳くわしい">くわ－しい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>551<br><h1> 鮮 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鮮%20%23kanji">Fresh</a></h1>Fish 。 。 。 sheep。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鮮 せん">セン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鮮あざやか">あざ－やか</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>552<br><h1> 達 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/達%20%23kanji">Accomplished</a></h1>The key word is meant to connote someone “skilled” at something。 On the road we find soil over a sheep。 You may have to work with this one a while longer。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/達 たつ">タツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>553<br><h1> 羨 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羨%20%23kanji">Envious</a></h1>Sheep 。 。 。 water 。 。 。 yawn／lack。 Although this character looks rather simple、 special care should be taken in learning it because of the proximity of the final two elements to the character for next、 which we learned in frame 471 次。 Note、 too、 that the water comes under the sheep、 rather than on its own to the left 。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羨 せん">セン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羨うらやむ">うらや－む</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/羨うらやましい">うらや－ましい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>554<br><h1> 差 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/差%20%23kanji">Distinction</a></h1>Wool 。 。 。 craft。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/差 さ">サ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/差さす">さ－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>555<br><h1> 着 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着%20%23kanji">Don</a></h1>I cannot resist doing this one for you、 since it clearly describes donning （putting on） one’s clothes as “pulling the wool over one’s eyes。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着 ちゃく">チャク</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着 じゃく">ジャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着きる">き－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着きせる">き－せる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着つく">つ－く</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/着つける">つ－ける</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>556<br><h1> 唯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唯%20%23kanji">Solely</a></h1>Mouth 。 。 。 turkey。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唯 ゆい">ユイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/唯 い">イ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>557<br><h1> 焦 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/焦%20%23kanji">Char</a></h1>Turkey 。 。 。 oven fire。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/焦 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/焦こげる">こ－げる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/焦こがす">こ－がす</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/焦こがれる">こ－がれる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/焦あせる">あせ－る</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>562<br><h1> 雑 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雑%20%23kanji">Miscellaneous</a></h1>Baseball 。 。 。 trees 。 。 。 turkey。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雑 ざつ">ザツ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雑 ぞう">ゾウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>563<br><h1> 雌 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雌%20%23kanji">Female</a></h1>This character for female forms a pair with that for male、 which we will learn later （frame 743 採）。 The elements： footprint 。 。 。 spoon 。 。 。 turkey。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雌 し">シ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雌 め">め</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雌 めす">めす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>564<br><h1> 準 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/準%20%23kanji">Semi</a></h1>Think of this in terms of the semifinals of some sports competition。 Water 。 。 。 turkeys 。 。 。 needle。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/準 じゅん">ジュン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>566<br><h1> 奪 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/奪%20%23kanji">Rob</a></h1>Whereas burglary （frame 357 賊） implies clandestine appropriation of another’s property、 robbery refers to taking by force。 The primitive elements： St。 Bernard dog 。 。 。 turkey 。 。 。 glue。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/奪 だつ">ダツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/奪うばう">うば－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>567<br><h1> 確 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/確%20%23kanji">Assurance</a></h1>On the left you see the rock、 which is familiar enough。 But pay attention to the right。 Taking careful note of the unusual stroke order that has the “chimney” on the house doubled up with the first stroke of the turkey、 we may see the right side as a turkey house （or “coop”）。 We shall see this pattern only on one other occasion （frame 1943 鶴）、 but even for these two characters it is well worth the trouble to single it out as a primitive。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/確 かく">カク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/確たしか">たし－か</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/確たしかめる">たし－かめる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>568<br><h1> 午 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/午%20%23kanji">Noon</a></h1>With a bit of stretching、 you might see a horse’s head pointing left ward in this character。 That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse、 which corresponds to the hour of noon。 Note how this kanji primitive diff ers from that for cow （frame 245 牛）。  As a primitive、 this character gets the meaning of a horse。 Any horse image will do、 except that of a team of horses、 which will come later （frame 1978 馬） and get its own primitive。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/午 ご">ゴ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>569<br><h1> 許 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/許%20%23kanji">Permit</a></h1>Words 。 。 。 horse。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/許 きょ">キョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/許ゆるす">ゆる－す</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>595<br><h1> 心 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/心%20%23kanji">Heart</a></h1>This character、 a pictographic representation of the heart、 is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet。  As a primitive、 it can take three forms、 to which we shall assign three distinct meanings。 In its kanji－form、 it appears beneath or to the right of its relative primitive and means the physical organ of the heart。 To the left、 it is abbreviated to three strokes、 忄、 and means a wildly emotional state of mind。 And finally、 at the very bottom、 it can take the form 胸、 in which case we give it the meaning of a valentine。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/心 しん">シン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/心 こころ">こころ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>615<br><h1> 感 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/感%20%23kanji">Emotion</a></h1>Mouths 。 。 。 marching 。 。 。 heart。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/感 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>616<br><h1> 憂 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憂%20%23kanji">Melancholy</a></h1>Head 。 。 。 crown 。 。 。 heart 。 。 。 walking legs。 Two things merit mention here。 First、 the doubling－up of the last stroke of head with the top of the crown serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful。 It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned。 Second、 try to make a single image out of the four elements。 （Religious statuary of melancholy figures should off er plenty of suggestions。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憂 ゆう">ユウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憂うれえる">うれ－える</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憂うれい">うれ－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憂うい">う－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>617<br><h1> 寡 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寡%20%23kanji">Widow</a></h1>House 。 。 。 head 。 。 。 dagger。 Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception。 Notice how the final stroke of the head is lengthened、 giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the dagger that fits in beneath。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/寡 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>618<br><h1> 忙 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/忙%20%23kanji">Busy</a></h1>State of mind 。 。 。 perish。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/忙 ぼう">ボウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/忙いそがしい">いそが－しい</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>620<br><h1> 恒 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/恒%20%23kanji">Constancy</a></h1>State of mind 。 。 。 span。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/恒 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>621<br><h1> 悼 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/悼%20%23kanji">Lament</a></h1>To keep this character distinct from others of similar connotation、 one need only think of the Prophet Jeremiah whose poetry gave an eminence to the state of mind we call lamentation。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/悼 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/悼いたむ">いた－む</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>622<br><h1> 悟 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/悟%20%23kanji">Enlightenment</a></h1>I know of an Indian religious sect which teaches that enlightenment is to be had by covering the eyes with one’s index fingers、 the ears with the thumbs、 and the mouth with the little fingers。 While these diff er a bit from the five holes that we used to represent the “I” （frame 17 吾）、 the idea of achieving a special state of mind by covering those five places can help you learn this kanji。 You might try the position out while you are learning this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/悟 ご">ゴ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/悟さとる">さと－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>623<br><h1> 怖 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/怖%20%23kanji">Dreadful</a></h1>State of mind 。 。 。 linen。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/怖 ふ">フ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/怖こわい">こわ－い</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>627<br><h1> 慣 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/慣%20%23kanji">Accustomed</a></h1>State of mind 。 。 。 pierce。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/慣 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/慣なれる">な－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/慣ならす">な－らす</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>631<br><h1> 憾 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憾%20%23kanji">Remorse</a></h1>State of mind 。 。 。 emotion。 Hint： the etymology of “remorse” indicates a memory that returns again and again to “bite at” one’s conscience and disturb one’s peace of mind。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/憾 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>635<br><h1> 必 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/必%20%23kanji">Invariably</a></h1>First note the stroke order of this character、 which did not really evolve from the heart、 even though we take it that way。 If one takes it as a pictograph “dividing” the heart in half、 then one has one of those invariably true bits of human anatomy： the fact that each heart is divided into two halves。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/必 ひつ">ヒツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/必かならず">かなら－ず</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>636<br><h1> 泌 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泌%20%23kanji">Ooze</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 the invariably divided heart。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泌 ひつ">ヒツ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/泌 ひ">ヒ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>637<br><h1> 手 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/手%20%23kanji">Hand</a></h1>Any way you count them、 there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a hand in this character。 But that it is、 and so you must。  Keep to the etymology when using this kanji as a primitive： a single hand all by itself。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/手 しゅ">シュ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/手 て">て</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/手 た">た</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>638<br><h1> 看 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/看%20%23kanji">Watch over</a></h1>Hand 。 。 。 eyes。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/看 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>639<br><h1> 摩 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/摩%20%23kanji">Chafe</a></h1>Hemp 。 。 。 hand。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/摩 ま">マ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>640<br><h1> 我 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/我%20%23kanji">Ego</a></h1>Hand 。 。 。 fiesta。 Note how the second stroke of the hand is stretched across to double up as the first stroke of the tasseled arrow we use for fiesta。 Compare to frames 17、 36、 and 525。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/我 が">ガ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/我 われ">われ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/我 わ">わ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>677<br><h1> 械 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/械%20%23kanji">Contraption</a></h1>Tree 。 。 。 commandment。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/械 かい">カイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>678<br><h1> 鼻 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鼻%20%23kanji">Nose</a></h1>Let me share a rather grotesque image to help with this kanji。 Imagine taking your two hands and reaching up into someone’s nostrils。 Once inside you grab hold of the brain and yank it out。 At the end、 you would have a picture something like that of this character、 the full kanji for nose。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鼻 び">ビ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鼻 はな">はな</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>679<br><h1> 刑 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刑%20%23kanji">Punish</a></h1>Two hands 。 。 。 saber。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刑 けい">ケイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>680<br><h1> 型 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/型%20%23kanji">Mould</a></h1>Punish 。 。 。 soil。 In cases like this、 you might find it easier to break the character up into its more basic elements、 like this： two hands 。 。 。 saber 。 。 。 soil。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/型 けい">ケイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/型 かた">かた</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>681<br><h1> 才 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/才%20%23kanji">Genius</a></h1>Whatever one is particularly adept at—one’s special “genius”— one can do very easily、 “with one finger” as the phrase goes。 This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger。 Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for fingers backwards。  The primitive meaning、genie、 derives from the roots of the word genius。 Use the genie out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive； in that case it also keeps its same form。 At the left 、 the form is altered to 能、 and the meaning becomes a genie in the bottle。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/才 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>682<br><h1> 財 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/財%20%23kanji">Property</a></h1>Clam 。 。 。 genie。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/財 ざい">ザイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/財 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>683<br><h1> 材 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/材%20%23kanji">Lumber</a></h1>Tree 。 。 。 genie。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/材 ざい">ザイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>684<br><h1> 存 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/存%20%23kanji">Suppose</a></h1>Genie in the bottle 。 。 。 a child。 Hint： focus on the key word’s connotation of “make believe”。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/存 そん">ソン</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/存 ぞん">ゾン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>685<br><h1> 在 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/在%20%23kanji">Exist</a></h1>Genie in the bottle 。 。 。 soil。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/在 ざい">ザイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/在ある">あ－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>686<br><h1> 乃 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乃%20%23kanji">From</a></h1>This pictograph of a clenched fist is another of the “handprimitives。” Take note of its rather peculiar drawing。 Try to think of drawing a fist （the primitive meaning） “from” this character to give yourself a connotation for the otherwise abstract key word。  The primitive meaning is taken from the pictograph：a fist。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>687<br><h1> 携 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/携%20%23kanji">Portable</a></h1>Fingers 。 。 。 turkey 。 。 。 fist。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/携 けい">ケイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/携たずさえる">たずさ－える</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/携たずさわる">たずさ－わる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>688<br><h1> 及 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/及%20%23kanji">Reach out</a></h1>The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched fist into the kanji for reaching out、 much as a stroke of kindness can often turn anger into acceptance。  As a primitive、 this shall stand for outstretched hands。 Only take care not to confuse it with that for beg （frame 462 乞）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/及 きゅう">キュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/及およぶ">およ－ぶ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/及および">およ－び</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/及およぼす">およ－ぼす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>689<br><h1> 吸 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吸%20%23kanji">Suck</a></h1>Mouth 。 。 。 outstretched hands。 Hint： use the image of a nursing baby。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吸 きゅう">キュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吸すう">す－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>690<br><h1> 扱 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/扱%20%23kanji">Handle</a></h1>Finger 。 。 。 outstretched hands。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/扱あつかう">あつか－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>691<br><h1> 丈 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丈%20%23kanji">Length</a></h1>The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length。 Notice the final stroke、 which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large （frame 107）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丈 じょう">ジョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丈 たけ">たけ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>692<br><h1> 史 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/史%20%23kanji">History</a></h1>A mouth 。 。 。 tucked under the arm。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/史 し">シ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>693<br><h1> 吏 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吏%20%23kanji">Officer</a></h1>One 。 。 。 mouth 。 。 。 tucked under the arm。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/吏 り">リ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>694<br><h1> 更 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/更%20%23kanji">Grow late</a></h1>The implication behind the meaning of grow late is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night。 The elements： ceiling 。 。 。 sun 。 。 。 tucked under the arm。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/更 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/更 さら">さら</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/更ふける">ふ－ける</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/更ふかす">ふ－かす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>695<br><h1> 硬 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/硬%20%23kanji">Stiff</a></h1>Rocks 。 。 。 grow late。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/硬 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/硬かたい">かた－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>696<br><h1> 又 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/又%20%23kanji">Or again</a></h1>Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate “and” （＋、 ＆、 etc。）、 this short two－stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of or again。  As a primitive、 it will mean crotch、 as in the crotch of the arm。 Or whatever。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/又 また">また</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>779<br><h1> 入 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/入%20%23kanji">Enter</a></h1>This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking left ward、 putting one leg forward in order to enter someplace。 Since the “in” side of a character is the left 、 it should be easy to remember the writing of this character。  As a primitive、 the meaning of the key word is expanded to include： to go in、 to put in、 to come in、 and the like。 It generally appears atop its relative primitive、 where、 unlike the element for umbrella 聿、 the two strokes do not touch each other、 making it virtually the same as the kanji for eight。 When it appears in any other position、 however、 it retains its original form。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/入 にゅう">ニュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/入いる">い－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/入いれる">い－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/入はいる">はい－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>780<br><h1> 込 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/込%20%23kanji">Crowded</a></h1>Enter 。 。 。 road。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/込こむ">こ－む</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/込こめる">こ－める</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>802<br><h1> 皮 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皮%20%23kanji">Pelt</a></h1>The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for branch。 The first stroke can then stand for something “hanging” down from the branch、 namely its bark or pelt。 The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change。 Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind。 By way of exception、 you might doodle around with the kanji’s form to see what you can come up with。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皮 ひ">ヒ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/皮 かわ">かわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>803<br><h1> 波 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/波%20%23kanji">Waves</a></h1>Water’s 。 。 。 pelt。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/波 は">ハ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/波 なみ">なみ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>836<br><h1> 環 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/環%20%23kanji">Ring</a></h1>Jewel 。 。 。 eye 。 。 。 ceiling 。 。 。 mouth 。 。 。 scarf。 The number of elements is large here、 so take care。 Learn it in conjunction with the next frame、 since these are the only two cases in this book where the combination of elements to the right appears。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/環 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>849<br><h1> 姫 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/姫%20%23kanji">Princess</a></h1>Woman 。 。 。 slave。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/姫 ひめ">ひめ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>856<br><h1> 巨 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/巨%20%23kanji">Gigantic</a></h1>This kanji depicts a gigantic “pop－eye、” which accounts for its shape。 Be sure not to confuse it with the slave （retainer） we just learned。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/巨 きょ">キョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>919<br><h1> 米 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/米%20%23kanji">Rice</a></h1>This kanji has a pictographic resemblance to a number of grains of rice lying on a plate in the shape of a star。  As a primitive、 it keeps its meaning of rice、 and is meant to connote a very ordinary、 commonplace grain、 in contrast to the primitive for wheat that we just learned。 （This meaning accords well with Japan、 where the output of rice far exceeds that of wheat。） It occasionally takes the shape 脊 when it stands on its own、 or is joined to a line above。 In this case、 we shall have it refer specifically to grains of rice。 This primitive is not to be confused with the similar－looking primitive for water。 While the stroke orders are nearly alike、 grains of rice has 5 strokes、 while water only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one。 Finally、 we may note that by itself the kanji for rice is an abbreviation used for the United States、 which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form、 if you so wish。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/米 べい">ベイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/米 まい">マイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/米 こめ">こめ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>920<br><h1> 粉 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/粉%20%23kanji">Flour</a></h1>Rice 。 。 。 part。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/粉 ふん">フン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/粉 こ">こ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/粉 こな">こな</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>934<br><h1> 求 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/求%20%23kanji">Request</a></h1>Let the drop in the upper right－hand corner of this character close the right angle off to make an arrowhead。 Whenever we find the needle with that drop in an element that has no other special meaning、 we will take advantage of this primitive meaning。 At the bottom、 we see the grains of rice、 the vertical line doubling up for the two elements。 Do not confuse with petition （frame 135 願）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/求 きゅう">キュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/求もとめる">もと－める</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>951<br><h1> 人 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/人%20%23kanji">Person</a></h1>The character for enter （frame 779 入） showed someone walking inwards （in terms of the direction of writing）。 The one for person、 shown here、 represents someone walking outwards。  As a primitive、 it can keep its kanji form except when it appears to the left （its normal position）、 where it is made to stand up in the form 脛。 The primitive meaning is another matter。 The abstract notion of person so often has a relation to the meaning of the kanji that confusion readily sets in。 So many of the previous stories have included people in them that simply to use person for a primitive meaning would be risky。 We need to be more specific、 to focus on one particular person。 Try to choose some－ one who has not figured in the stories so far、 perhaps a colorful member of the family or a friend whom you have known for a long time。 That individual will appear again and again、 so be sure to choose someone who excites your imagination。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/人 じん">ジン</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/人 にん">ニン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/人 ひと">ひと</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>952<br><h1> 佐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/佐%20%23kanji">Assistant</a></h1>Person 。 。 。 left 。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/佐 さ">サ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1016<br><h1> 久 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/久%20%23kanji">Long time</a></h1>This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for bound up and a person。 Think of a mummy、 and the key word will not be far behind。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/久 きゅう">キュウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/久 く">ク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/久ひさしい">ひさ－しい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1017<br><h1> 畝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畝%20%23kanji">Furrow</a></h1>Think of the three kinds of furrows shown here in this character—a top hat’s rim、 a rice field’s ridges、 and the wrinkles that show you’ve been around a long time。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畝 うね">うね</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1018<br><h1> 囚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/囚%20%23kanji">Captured</a></h1>Person 。 。 。 pent in。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/囚 しゅう">シュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1019<br><h1> 内 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/内%20%23kanji">Inside</a></h1>Person 。 。 belt。 Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of hood here because the person runs through the element、 not under it。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/内 ない">ナイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/内 だい">ダイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/内 うち">うち</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1020<br><h1> 丙 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丙%20%23kanji">Third class</a></h1>Those no－frills flights the airlines off er to attract customers should help create an image from ceiling 。 。 。 person 。 。 。 belt。 The kanji meaning “inside” should not be used because of its proximity to the element for “in。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/丙 へい">ヘイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1021<br><h1> 柄 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柄%20%23kanji">Design</a></h1>Tree 。 。 。 third class。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柄 へい">ヘイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柄 がら">がら</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/柄 え">え</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1022<br><h1> 肉 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肉%20%23kanji">Meat</a></h1>Let this doubling of one of the elements for “inside” yield the sense of “insides” to approach the key word、 meat。 The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of flesh or part of the body for the kanji 月。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/肉 にく">ニク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1023<br><h1> 腐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腐%20%23kanji">Rot</a></h1>Municipality 。 。 。 meat。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腐 ふ">フ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腐くさる">くさ－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腐くされる">くさ－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/腐くさらす">くさ－らす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1024<br><h1> 座 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/座%20%23kanji">Sit</a></h1>Cave 。 。 。 assembly line 。 。 。 soil。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/座 ざ">ザ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/座すわる">すわ－る</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1027<br><h1> 匁 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/匁%20%23kanji">Monme</a></h1>This character obliges us to use a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent。 It refers to an old unit of weight、 equal to about 3。75 grams。 The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English。 Its primitives、 if you look closely、 are： bound up 。 。 。 arm。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1028<br><h1> 以 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/以%20%23kanji">By means of</a></h1>Picture a person dragging a plow behind、 and the drop of sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work。 Think of him （or her、 for that matter） making a living “by means of the sweat of their brows。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/以 い">イ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1029<br><h1> 似 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/似%20%23kanji">Similar</a></h1>Be sure to keep this key word distinct from likeness （frame 100）。 Its elements： person 。 。 。 by means of。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/似 じ">ジ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/似にる">に－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1030<br><h1> 併 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/併%20%23kanji">Join</a></h1>The sense of the key word is one of joining things together that were previously separate。 Its elements： person 。 。 。 puzzle。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/併 へい">ヘイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/併あわせる">あわ－せる</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1035<br><h1> 善 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/善%20%23kanji">Virtuous</a></h1>Sheep 。 。 。 horns 。 。 。 mouth。 Pay special attention to the writing of this character。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/善 ぜん">ゼン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/善よい">よ－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1036<br><h1> 年 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/年%20%23kanji">Year</a></h1>In an odd fashion、 the kanji for year joins together the element for horse、 on the top、 and the right half of the element for sunglasses。 Think of it as a horse wearing sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out。 We will use this latter image again、 so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/年 ねん">ネン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/年 とし">とし</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1037<br><h1> 夜 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夜%20%23kanji">Night</a></h1>First of all、 be sure not to confuse the connotations of night with those of evening （frame 109） and nightbreak （frame 30 旦）。 Its elements： top hat 。 。 person 。 。 。walking legs 。 。 。 drop。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夜 や">ヤ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夜 よ">よ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/夜 よる">よる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1038<br><h1> 液 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/液%20%23kanji">Fluid</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 night。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/液 えき">エキ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1042<br><h1> 喚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/喚%20%23kanji">Yell</a></h1>The mouth on the left is obvious。 The rest is harder。 Try this： four St。 Bernard dogs bound up in a bunch。 Togetherthey should supply a clear enough portrait of a yell、 provided you are careful to see all four of them。 Note how the final stroke of the four is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the St。 Bernard。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/喚 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1043<br><h1> 換 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/換%20%23kanji">Interchange</a></h1>Fingers 。 。 。 four St。 Bernard dogs bound up。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/換 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/換かえる">か－える</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/換かわる">か－わる</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1069<br><h1> 刷 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刷%20%23kanji">Printing</a></h1>Flag 。 。 。 towel 。 。 。 saber。 shaku 。 The key word shaku has actually come into English in the word shakuhachi、 the ancient Japanese flute that measured “one shaku and eight sun” （the “sun” being about an inch in length）。 Since the shaku is about one foot in length、 this makes about 　inches。 Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the flag。  As a primitive、 this will mean the shakuhachi flute。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刷 さつ">サツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/刷する">す－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1070<br><h1> 尺 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/尺%20%23kanji">Shaku</a></h1>As a primitive、 this will mean the shakuhachi flute.<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/尺 しゃく">シャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1105<br><h1> 由 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/由%20%23kanji">Wherefore</a></h1>The “wherefore” of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing。 It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a rice field sending up a single sprout、 which is the whole why and wherefore of the seed’s falling in the earth and dying。 （When the flower appears、 you will recall from frame 234 苗、 we have a full seedling。）  As a primitive、 in conformity to the explanation above、 this kanji will be taken to mean shoot or sprout。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/由 ゆ">ユ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/由 ゆう">ユウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/由 ゆい">ユイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/由 よし">よし</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1106<br><h1> 抽 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/抽%20%23kanji">Pluck</a></h1>Fingers 。 。 。 sprout。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/抽 ちゅう">チュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1115<br><h1> 岬 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/岬%20%23kanji">Headland</a></h1>Like the cape （frame 153 埼） and the promontory （frame 778 崎）、 the headland refers to a jut of land。 Its elements： mountain 。 。 。 roots。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/岬 みさき">みさき</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1117<br><h1> 申 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/申%20%23kanji">Speaketh</a></h1>The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb “to speak。” It is written by a tongue wagging in the mouth with a walking stick rammed through it and coming out at both ends。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/申 しん">シン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/申もうす">もう－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1118<br><h1> 伸 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伸%20%23kanji">Expand</a></h1>Person 。 。 。 monkey。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伸 しん">シン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伸のびる">の－びる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伸のばす">の－ばす</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伸のべる">の－べる</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1120<br><h1> 捜 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/捜%20%23kanji">Search</a></h1>Fingers 。 。 。 monkey 。 。 。 crotch。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/捜 そう">ソウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/捜さがす">さが－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1121<br><h1> 果 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/果%20%23kanji">Fruit</a></h1>The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth （the tree） and comes to fruition、 producing fruit full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again。 The main thing to notice here is the element for brains at the top、 which might prove more helpful than rice field for creating an image。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/果 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/果はたす">は－たす</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/果はてる">は－てる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/果はて">は－て</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1168<br><h1> 両 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/両%20%23kanji">Both</a></h1>Ceiling 。 。 。 belt 。 。 。 mountain。 Note that the writing order follows the order in which the primitives are given here。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/両 りょう">リョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
