<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1170<br><h1> 画 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/画%20%23kanji">Brush－stroke</a></h1>In forming an image for the key word、 it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations such as completed paintings、 as well as for the number of brush－strokes in a character （as、 for instance、 in Indexes ii and iii at the end of this book）。 Its elements are： ceiling 。 。 。 sprout 。 。 。 shovel。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/画 が">ガ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/画 かく">カク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1171<br><h1> 歯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/歯%20%23kanji">Tooth</a></h1>Footprint 。 。 。 rice 。 。 。 shovel。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/歯 し">シ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/歯 は">は</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1172<br><h1> 曲 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/曲%20%23kanji">Bend</a></h1>Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart、 thus giving the sense of bend。 If you think of them as deriving from the element for brains beneath （of course、 the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of）、 you can associate the key word with bending someone’s mind to your own point of view。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/曲 きょく">キョク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/曲まがる">ま－がる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/曲まげる">ま－げる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1173<br><h1> 曹 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/曹%20%23kanji">Cadet</a></h1>This character is written in the order of its elements： one 。 。 。 bend 。 。 。 sun。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/曹 そう">ソウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1175<br><h1> 漕 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/漕%20%23kanji">Rowing</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 cadet。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1176<br><h1> 槽 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/槽%20%23kanji">Vat</a></h1>Tree 。 。 。 cadet。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/槽 そう">ソウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1177<br><h1> 斗 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/斗%20%23kanji">Big Dipper</a></h1>The Big Dipper here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major、 of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation。  Since we already have a primitive element for a “dipper”— namely、 the ladle—we shall let this one stand for a measuring cup。 By the way、 it would make a rather large one、 since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters！<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/斗 と">ト</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1178<br><h1> 料 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/料%20%23kanji">Fee</a></h1>Measuring cup 。 。 。 rice。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/料 りょう">リョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1179<br><h1> 科 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/科%20%23kanji">Department</a></h1>Think here of the faculty or department you entered in university、 using the elements： measuring cup 。 。 。 wheat。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/科 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1180<br><h1> 図 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/図%20%23kanji">Map</a></h1>Pent in 。 。 。 Big Dipper。 Hint： among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called “Follow the Drinking Gourd。” It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves （those pent in） who had no maps other than the stars to guide them、 among them the bright and predominant Big Dipper、 the “Drinking Gourd。”<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/図 ず">ズ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/図 と">ト</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/図はかる">はか－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1181<br><h1> 用 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/用%20%23kanji">Utilize</a></h1>Meat 。 。 。 walking stick。 Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for use （frame 990 使）。 The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given。  As a primitive element、 we shall substitute the image of a screwdriver、 perhaps the most utilized of all tools around the house。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/用 よう">ヨウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/用もちいる">もち－いる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1182<br><h1> 庸 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/庸%20%23kanji">Comfortable</a></h1>Cave 。 。 。 rake 。 。 。 screwdriver。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/庸 よう">ヨウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1184<br><h1> 昔 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昔%20%23kanji">Once upon a time</a></h1>Salad 。 。 。 days。 This is the character with which Japanese fairy tales commonly begin。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昔 せき">セキ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昔 しゃく">シャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/昔 むかし">むかし</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1201<br><h1> 暁 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暁%20%23kanji">Daybreak</a></h1>Sun 。 。 。 straw man。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暁 ぎょう">ギョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暁 あかつき">あかつき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1202<br><h1> 半 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/半%20%23kanji">Half</a></h1>Although the writing order is diff erent、 one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a little needle—the kind used for splitting hairs in half。 （Again、 according to rule、 little takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top。）<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/半 はん">ハン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/半なかば">なか－ば</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1203<br><h1> 伴 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伴%20%23kanji">Consort</a></h1>Person 。 。 。 half。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伴 はん">ハン</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伴 ばん">バン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/伴ともなう">ともな－う</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1204<br><h1> 畔 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畔%20%23kanji">Paddy ridge</a></h1>Rice field 。 。 。 half。 The key word here refers to the ridges that rise up between the sections of a rice paddy。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/畔 はん">ハン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1205<br><h1> 判 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/判%20%23kanji">Judgment</a></h1>Half 。 。 。 saber。 You might recall the famous judgment of King Solomon、 who off ered to slice a baby in two with a saber to give half to each of the mothers who claimed it as her own。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/判 はん">ハン</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/判 ばん">バン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1206<br><h1> 券 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/券%20%23kanji">Ticket</a></h1>Quarter 。 。 。 dagger。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/券 けん">ケン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1207<br><h1> 巻 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/巻%20%23kanji">Scroll</a></h1>Quarter 。 。 。 snake。 The key word refers to a manuscript rolled up into a scroll、 not to a hanging scroll （frame 407 幅）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/巻 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/巻まく">ま－く</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/巻 まき">まき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1208<br><h1> 圏 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/圏%20%23kanji">Sphere</a></h1>This key word refers to a realm or orbit、 not to a ball。 Its elements： pent in 。 。 。 scroll。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/圏 けん">ケン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1209<br><h1> 勝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勝%20%23kanji">Victory</a></h1>Moon 。 。 。 quarter 。 。 。 muscle。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勝 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勝かつ">か－つ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/勝まさる">まさ－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1210<br><h1> 藤 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/藤%20%23kanji">Wisteria</a></h1>Flower 。 。 。 moon 。 。 。 quarter 。 。 。 rice grains。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/藤 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/藤 ふじ">ふじ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1211<br><h1> 謄 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/謄%20%23kanji">Facsimile</a></h1>Moon 。 。 。 quarter 。 。 。 words。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/謄 とう">トウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1212<br><h1> 片 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/片%20%23kanji">One－sided</a></h1>This kanji is based on the pictograph of a tree with some branches going upwards and others hanging down、 split right down the middle。 When that picture’s right side is isolated、 it becomes the kanji for one－sided、 in the sense of only one part of a whole。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/片 へん">ヘン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/片 かた">かた</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1213<br><h1> 版 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/版%20%23kanji">Printing block</a></h1>Although this character also carries the sense of an “edition” of a publication、 the elements、 one－sided and anti－、 more readily suggest its other meaning of a printing block。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/版 はん">ハン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1214<br><h1> 之 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/之%20%23kanji">Of</a></h1>This character is now used chiefly in proper names、 and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え、 though in fact it has no relation to it。  In order to give this kanji a more concrete meaning when it is used as a primitive element、 think of it as referring to building blocks with the hiragana written on them、 much the same as the a－b－c blocks you played with as a child。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1215<br><h1> 乏 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乏%20%23kanji">Destitution</a></h1>Drop of 。 。 。 building blocks。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乏 ぼう">ボウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/乏とぼしい">とぼ－しい</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1216<br><h1> 芝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/芝%20%23kanji">Turf</a></h1>Flowers 。 。 。 building blocks。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/芝 しば">しば</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1217<br><h1> 不 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/不%20%23kanji">Negative</a></h1>You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish （ceiling 。 。 。 person 。 。 。 a drop of）、 but you will probably find that its simplicity、 and its frequency、 make it easy to remember just as it is。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/不 ふ">フ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/不 ぶ">ブ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1219<br><h1> 杯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杯%20%23kanji">Cupfuls</a></h1>Tree 。 。 。 negative。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杯 はい">ハイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/杯 さかずき">さかずき</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1220<br><h1> 矢 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/矢%20%23kanji">Dart</a></h1>When shot high into the heavens、 the dart gets so small it looks like a mere drop。 Although this character could as well mean “arrow、” it has no connection with the primitive of that meaning。 Hence the new key word。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/矢 し">シ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/矢 や">や</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1228<br><h1> 霧 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/霧%20%23kanji">Fog</a></h1>Weather／rain 。 。 。 task。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/霧 む">ム</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/霧 きり">きり</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1231<br><h1> 弓 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弓%20%23kanji">Bow</a></h1>This character pictures the bent wooden bow。 Later we will learn how to make the bowstring that goes with it （frame 1386 弦）。 If you stretch this character out and see the indentation on the left as its handle、 the pictography should be clearer。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弓 きゅう">キュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弓 ゆみ">ゆみ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1235<br><h1> 強 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強%20%23kanji">Strong</a></h1>Vast 。 。 。 insect。 Note how the elbow of vast is shrunken and elevated to make room for the insect beneath。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強 きょう">キョウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強 ごう">ゴウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強つよい">つよ－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強つよまる">つよ－まる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強つよめる">つよ－める</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/強しいる">し－いる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1236<br><h1> 弱 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弱%20%23kanji">Weak</a></h1>Two bows 。 。 with ice on them。  dollar sign 弗 Composed of two walking sticks running through a bow、 this character is infrequent as a primitive、 and yet easy to remember for what it looks like （which is also what the Japanese adopted it to mean in days gone by）： the dollar sign、 ＄。 When it is written under another element、 the first vertical stroke is abbreviated to a short “tail” as the final stroke、 and the second vertical stroke is cut off at the top。 Examples follow in frames<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弱 じゃく">ジャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弱よわい">よわ－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弱よわる">よわ－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弱よわまる">よわ－まる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/弱よわめる">よわ－める</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1237<br><h1> 沸 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沸%20%23kanji">Seethe</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 dollar sign。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沸 ふつ">フツ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沸わく">わ－く</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沸わかす">わ－かす</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1245<br><h1> 汚 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚%20%23kanji">Dirty</a></h1>Water 。 。 。 two 。 。 。 snare。 Note that the first stroke for snare doubles up with the first stroke for two。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚 お">オ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚けがす">けが－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚けがれる">けが－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚けがらわしい">けが－らわしい</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚よごす">よご－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚よごれる">よご－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汚きたない">きたな－い</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1246<br><h1> 与 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/与%20%23kanji">Bestow</a></h1>Slingshot 。 。 。 one。 Later on we shall learn the character for give （frame 1897 呉）、 but even at this point it is a good idea to distinguish this key word from impart （frame 736 授） and grant （frame 1052 賜）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/与 よ">ヨ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/与あたえる">あた－える</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1247<br><h1> 写 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/写%20%23kanji">Copy</a></h1>Crown 。 。 。 bestow。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/写 しゃ">シャ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/写うつす">うつ－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/写うつる">うつ－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1248<br><h1> 身 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/身%20%23kanji">Somebody</a></h1>The key word somebody was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji： body and person。 Its composition is based on the nose （which、 you will recall、 is also the kanji for oneself）。 The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element、 together with the unusual diagonal stroke、 forms the pictograph of somebody with a prominent paunch。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/身 しん">シン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/身 み">み</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1249<br><h1> 射 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/射%20%23kanji">Shoot</a></h1>“I shot an arrow into the air、 And it landed I know not where” goes the poem。 （The poor poet obviously loses a lot of arrows。） This kanji、 however、 tells us where it did land。 Its elements： somebody 。 。 。 glued to。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/射 しゃ">シャ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/射いる">い－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1250<br><h1> 謝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/謝%20%23kanji">Apologize</a></h1>Words 。 。 。 shoot。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/謝 しゃ">シャ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/謝あやまる">あやま－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1251<br><h1> 老 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/老%20%23kanji">Old man</a></h1>First、 do not confuse this character with venerable old man （frame 786 翁）、 which is far more rarely used。 The character for an old man begins with an abbreviation of the character for somebody、 the nose having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines。 But there is another、 simpler way to remember it all： the soil drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when “dust to dust” begins to take on a personal meaning； the diagonal walking stick for getting around； and the spoon for being spoon－fed。  As a primitive、 the meaning is the same、 but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements： 臘。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/老 ろう">ロウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/老おいる">お－いる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/老ふける">ふ－ける</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1252<br><h1> 考 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/考%20%23kanji">Consider</a></h1>Old man 。 。 。 slingshot。 Remember： you already have kanji for discriminating （frame 482 識）、 deliberation （frame 642 議）、 and think （frame 605 思）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/考 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/考かんがえる">かんが－える</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1253<br><h1> 孝 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/孝%20%23kanji">Filial piety</a></h1>Old man 。 。 。 child。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/孝 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1279<br><h1> 足 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/足%20%23kanji">Leg</a></h1>Mouth 。 。 。 mending。 Note that the last stroke of mouth and the first of mending overlap。  As a primitive on the left、 it is amended to 脣。 Its meaning remains leg、 but should be thought of as a wooden leg in order to avoid confusion with other similar elements、 namely human legs、 animal legs、 and walking legs。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/足 そく">ソク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/足 あし">あし</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/足たりる">た－りる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/足たる">た－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/足たす">た－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1280<br><h1> 促 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/促%20%23kanji">Stimulate</a></h1>Person 。 。 。 leg。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/促 そく">ソク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/促うながす">うなが－す</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1362<br><h1> 約 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/約%20%23kanji">Promise</a></h1>Consider for a moment the etymology of the word “promise” in order to notice its roots in the activity of putting one thing （e。g。、 one’s word of honor） in place of another （e。g。、 the fulfillment of a task）。 For as it turns out、 this character also means “to abridge、 economize、 and abbreviate”—all activities that involve putting one thing in place of another。 With that in mind、 we may now work with the elements： thread 。 。 。 ladle。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/約 やく">ヤク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1426<br><h1> 興 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/興%20%23kanji">Entertain</a></h1>Here we see a wheel of fortune that has been tampered with。 On both sides you see the staples separating one number’s slot from the next、 and between them the character for the same— indicating that it has been rigged to repeat the same number。 The tool below refers to the wheel itself。 A dandy form of entertainment、 especially if you are the owner of the wheel。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/興 こう">コウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/興 きょう">キョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/興おこる">おこ－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/興おこす">おこ－す</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1440<br><h1> 豆 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豆%20%23kanji">Beans</a></h1>This kanji depicts a pot of beans、 although it looks more like a table on which the pot is resting。  As a primitive、 this kanji will also mean table。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豆 とう">トウ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豆 ず">ズ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/豆 まめ">まめ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1519<br><h1> 亥 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/亥%20%23kanji">Sign of the hog</a></h1>This kanji is the 12th sign of the Chinese zodiac： the sign of the hog。 It is best learned by thinking of an acorn－eating hog in connection with the primitive meaning given below。  The top hat represents the external shape of the acorn、and the unusual but easily written complex of strokes beneath it （which you might also see as distortions of an elbow and person） stands for the mysterious secret whereby the acorn contains the oak tree in a nutshell。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1588<br><h1> 含 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/含%20%23kanji">Include</a></h1>Clock 。 。 。 mouth。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/含 がん">ガン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/含ふくむ">ふく－む</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/含ふくめる">ふく－める</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1593<br><h1> 予 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/予%20%23kanji">Beforehand</a></h1>Think of this character as identical to the halberd （frame 1225 矛） except that the final stroke has been omitted。 Return to that character and devise some image to take this diff erence into account。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/予 よ">ヨ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1596<br><h1> 野 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/野%20%23kanji">Plains</a></h1>This character refers to rustic life and rustic fields primarily、 and from there gets derived meanings。 Its elements： computer 。 。 。 beforehand。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/野 や">ヤ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/野 の">の</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1597<br><h1> 兼 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兼%20%23kanji">Concurrently</a></h1>At the top we have the animal horns and the single horizontal stroke to give them something to hang onto。 Below that、 we see one rake with two handles。 Finally、 we see a pair of strokes splitting away from each of the handles、 indicating that they are both splitting under the pressure。 The composite picture is of someone holding down two jobs concurrently、 using the same kit of tools to move in two diff erent directions and ending up in a mess。 Take the time to find this sense in the kanji and it will be easy to remember、 despite initial appearances。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兼 けん">ケン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/兼かねる">か－ねる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1598<br><h1> 嫌 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫌%20%23kanji">Dislike</a></h1>Woman 。 。 。 concurrently。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫌 けん">ケン</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫌 げん">ゲン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫌きらう">きら－う</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/嫌 いや">いや</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1602<br><h1> 西 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/西%20%23kanji">West</a></h1>To our way of counting directions、 the west always comes fourth。 So it is convenient to find the character for four in this kanji。 But since we want only one of the four directions、 the west adds the one at the top and sucks the human legs a bit out of their mouth in the process。  As a primitive、 the meaning of west can be expanded to refer to the Old West of cowboy－movie fame、 just as the meaning of the character for east was expanded into the East。 Note、 however、 that in its primitive form the legs are straightened out and reach down to the bottom of the mouth。 Hence、 we get the shape 臠。 With the exception of one kanji、 given in the following frame、 this element always appears at the top of its relative primitives。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/西 せい">セイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/西 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/西 にし">にし</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1632<br><h1> 非 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/非%20%23kanji">Un</a></h1>This key word、 a negating prefix、 is a doodle of a heavy iron pole with bars extending in both directions、 to create the picture of a jail cell。 From there to “un－” is but a short step。  As a primitive、 we shall draw on the explanation above for the meaning of jail cell。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/非 ひ">ヒ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1648<br><h1> 干 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/干%20%23kanji">Dry</a></h1>It is best to see this kanji as a pictograph of a revolving circular clothesline （viewed from the side）。 Spin it around quickly in your mind’s eye to give it the connotation of to dry。  The primitive meaning is clothesline。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/干 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/干ほす">ほ－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/干ひる">ひ－る</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1757<br><h1> 甘 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/甘%20%23kanji">Sweet</a></h1>This kanji is a pictograph of a small wicker basket。 （The extra short stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the character for twenty。） All one needs to add is some image of sweet cakes or breads carried in the basket、 and the union of picture and meaning is complete。 Take care not to confuse with confectionary （frame 1122 族）。  As a primitive、 the pictograph’s meaning of a wicker basket is used、 a small one like the kind used for picnics。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/甘 かん">カン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/甘あまい">あま－い</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/甘あまえる">あま－える</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/甘あまやかす">あま－やかす</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1781<br><h1> 査 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/査%20%23kanji">Investigate</a></h1>Tree 。 。 。 shelf。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/査 さ">サ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1782<br><h1> 助 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/助%20%23kanji">Help</a></h1>Shelf 。 。 。 power。 The reason why the shelf appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power、 the stronger primitive。 Indeed、 the only exception in all the kanji is the character for add （frame 867 加）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/助 じょ">ジョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/助たすける">たす－ける</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/助たすかる">たす－かる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/助 すけ">すけ</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1785<br><h1> 並 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/並%20%23kanji">Row</a></h1>This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for stand up。 By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes、 you will see how this is done。  The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji、but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo。 It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book。 When it appears beneath its relative primitive、 the top three strokes are omitted、 though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it： 脯。 atop its relative primitive、 it can keep its kanji shape。 When it does not、 the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced below the primitive’s bottom line： 脱。 We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to upside down in a row。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/並 へい">ヘイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/並 なみ">なみ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/並ならべる">なら－べる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/並ならぶ">なら－ぶ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/並ならびに">なら－びに</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1786<br><h1> 普 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/普%20%23kanji">Universal</a></h1>Row 。 。 。 sun。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/普 ふ">フ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1795<br><h1> 共 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/共%20%23kanji">Together</a></h1>Salad 。 。 。 animal legs。  The primitive retains the meaning of together。Imagine things strung together like fish on a line、 beads on a thread、 or whatever。 The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row、 which would confound this element with the previous one。 As we saw with bushel basket、 this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/共 きょう">キョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/共 とも">とも</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1865<br><h1> 詞 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詞%20%23kanji">Parts of speech</a></h1>The key word、 parts of speech、 refers to nouns、 verbs、 adjective、 adverbs、 and so on。 The elements： words 。 。 。 directors。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/詞 し">シ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1868<br><h1> 舟 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舟%20%23kanji">Boat</a></h1>After the drop and the glass canopy、 we come to a combination of three strokes that we met only once before、 in the character for mama （frame 101）。 The pictographic meaning we gave it there has no etymological relationship to this character、 but use it if it helps。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舟 しゅう">シュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舟 ふね">ふね</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舟 ふな">ふな</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1869<br><h1> 舶 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舶%20%23kanji">Liner</a></h1>The type of boat connoted by this key word is a large oceangoing liner。 The important thing here is to work with the elements boat and dove to make an image distinct from that of the former frame。 Don’t count on size alone to distinguish the boat from the liner。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/舶 はく">ハク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1870<br><h1> 航 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/航%20%23kanji">Navigate</a></h1>Boat 。 。 。 whirlwind。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/航 こう">コウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
