<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1880<br><h1> 繭 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/繭%20%23kanji">Cocoon</a></h1>Though it’s a good thing that the primitive for cocoon has been radically abbreviated from this、 its full form as a kanji、 the story it holds is a charming one。 The silkworm （insect） eats the leaves of the mulberry bush （the flowers）、 digests them and transforms them into thread with which it spins about itself、 in mystic wisdom、 its own coffin （the hood）。 The dividing line that separates the two elements helps the picture of the little worm cutting itself off from contact with the outside world、 but as a character stroke、 it is a clear exception。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/繭 けん">ケン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/繭 まゆ">まゆ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1881<br><h1> 益 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/益%20%23kanji">Benefit</a></h1>Poised over the dish is a pair of animal horns that are attached to a pair of animal legs by a single horizontal stroke。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/益 えき">エキ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/益 やく">ヤク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1882<br><h1> 暇 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暇%20%23kanji">Spare time</a></h1>The element for day on the left is logical enough。 Next to it we see staples being held in a mouth （one stroke is doubled up）、 indicating working on one’s hobby or handicraft s at home in one’s spare time。 The small box at the top right is facing backwards、 or more properly “inside out。” Finally、 we have the crotch at the bottom。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暇 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/暇 ひま">ひま</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1883<br><h1> 敷 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敷%20%23kanji">Spread</a></h1>At the top we have the arrowhead whose vertical line joins it to the rice field （or brains） below it。 Beneath it、 the compass； and to the right、 the taskmaster。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敷 ふ">フ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/敷しく">し－く</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1884<br><h1> 来 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/来%20%23kanji">Come</a></h1>This odd but common kanji is built up of the character for not yet into which a pair of animal horns has been inserted。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/来 らい">ライ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/来くる">く－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/来きたる">きた－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/来きたす">きた－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1885<br><h1> 気 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/気%20%23kanji">Spirit</a></h1>The spirit in this character refers to the changeable moods and airs of one’s personality as well as to the more essential combination of vital forces that distinguish things and individuals one from the other。 Its elements are： reclining 。 。 。  。 。 。 fishhook 。 。 。 sheaf。 Do not confuse with spirits （frame 1791 霊）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/気 き">キ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/気 け">ケ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1886<br><h1> 汽 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汽%20%23kanji">Vapor</a></h1>Think of this character as a sibling of that for spirit。 Simply replace sheaves with drops of water on the left in order to get vapor。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/汽 き">キ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1887<br><h1> 飛 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/飛%20%23kanji">Fly</a></h1>The two large hooks have little propellers （the two drops on each hook） attached to them for flying。 Beneath is the measuring box、 which serves as the body of this flying contraption。 The stroke order will cause some problems、 so take care with it。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/飛 ひ">ヒ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/飛とぶ">と－ぶ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/飛とばす">と－ばす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1888<br><h1> 沈 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沈%20%23kanji">Sink</a></h1>The technique for sinking used in this kanji is unique。 Rather than the biblical image of tying a millstone about the victim’s neck、 here we see a crown tied about one leg before the unfortunate party is tossed into the water。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沈 ちん">チン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沈しずむ">しず－む</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/沈しずめる">しず－める</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1889<br><h1> 妻 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妻%20%23kanji">Wife</a></h1>Ten 。 。 。 rakes 。 。 。 woman。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妻 さい">サイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/妻 つま">つま</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1890<br><h1> 衰 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/衰%20%23kanji">Decline</a></h1>Let this key word connote the decline and fall of the Roman Empire。 It shows a fellow in a top hat and scarf、 trying hard to look happy by putting a walking stick in his mouth sideways to twist his face into a grotesque but semipermanent smile。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/衰 すい">スイ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/衰おとろえる">おとろ－える</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1891<br><h1> 衷 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/衷%20%23kanji">Inmost</a></h1>Between the top hat and the scarf you will see the character for in which is truncated at the bottom so as not to interfere with the scarf。 You can think of this character as forming a pair with the one just learned in the last frame： there the in （the walking stick in the mouth） was set on its side； in this character it is set upright。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/衷 ちゅう">チュウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1892<br><h1> 面 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/面%20%23kanji">Mask</a></h1>Imagine a mask over your head with eyes peeping not only out of the normal place、 but from all over the head、 a hundred in all （the element for eye displacing the fifth stroke of that for hundred）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/面 めん">メン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/面 おも">おも</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/面 おもて">おもて</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/面 つら">つら</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1893<br><h1> 革 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/革%20%23kanji">Leather</a></h1>After the flowers at the top （painted on the leather for decoration）、 we see the element for car with the middle stroke left out。 Think of the seats having been taken out so that they can be reupholstered with this decorated leather。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/革 かく">カク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/革 かわ">かわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1894<br><h1> 靴 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/靴%20%23kanji">Shoes</a></h1>Leather 。 。 。 change。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/靴 か">カ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/靴 くつ">くつ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1895<br><h1> 覇 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覇%20%23kanji">Hegemony</a></h1>Old West 。 。 。 leather 。 。 。 moon。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/覇 は">ハ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1896<br><h1> 声 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/声%20%23kanji">Voice</a></h1>The samurai at the top is familiar enough。 The combination beneath、 which looks like a flag with a line running through it、 is not。 Try to devise some way to take note of it、 and pay attention to the writing。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/声 せい">セイ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/声 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/声 こえ">こえ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/声 こわ">こわ</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1897<br><h1> 呉 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呉%20%23kanji">Give</a></h1>The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult、 because of the fourth stroke、 which is rare （see frames 33 and 34）。 The mouth and tool are already familiar。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/呉 ご">ゴ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1898<br><h1> 娯 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/娯%20%23kanji">Recreation</a></h1>Woman 。 。 。 give。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/娯 ご">ゴ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1899<br><h1> 誤 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/誤%20%23kanji">Mistake</a></h1>Words 。 。 。 give。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/誤 ご">ゴ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/誤あやまる">あやま－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1900<br><h1> 蒸 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/蒸%20%23kanji">Steam</a></h1>The flower at the top and the  with the oven fire beneath are familiar。 The problem is what comes in between。 It is formed by the character for complete、 whose vertical stroke doubles up as the first stroke of water。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/蒸 じょう">ジョウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/蒸むす">む－す</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/蒸むれる">む－れる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/蒸むらす">む－らす</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1901<br><h1> 承 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/承%20%23kanji">Acquiesce</a></h1>The sense of passive acceptance or reception of information is contained in this key word。 The form is based on the middle portion of the preceding character、 with three additional strokes、 best thought of as the kanji for three。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/承 しょう">ショウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/承うけたまわる">うけたまわ－る</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1902<br><h1> 函 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/函%20%23kanji">Bin</a></h1>This is the character from which the element for shovel derives。 Within it comes the element for snare、 with the sparkler surrounding it。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1903<br><h1> 極 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/極%20%23kanji">Poles</a></h1>The poles this key word refers to are the extremities of the earth or the terminals of an electric field。 The elements are： tree 。 。 。 snare 。 。 。 mouth 。 。 。 crotch 。 。 。 。 <br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/極 きょく">キョク</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/極 ごく">ゴク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/極きわめる">きわ－める</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/極きわまる">きわ－まる</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/極きわみ">きわ－み</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1904<br><h1> 牙 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牙%20%23kanji">Tusk</a></h1>If you play with this primitive’s form with pencil and paper、 you will see that it begins with a box－like shape、 and ends with the final two strokes of the halberd、 a convenient combination for the tusk protruding from the mouth of an animal。  Since this kanji has 4 strokes、 you would expect that as a primitive it would also have 4—but in fact it has 5 in the following two frames （the second stroke between divided into 2 strokes） and reverts to 4 again in frame 1907 雅。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牙 が">ガ</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牙 げ">ゲ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/牙 きば">きば</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1905<br><h1> 芽 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/芽%20%23kanji">Bud</a></h1>Flowers 。 。 。 tusk。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/芽 が">ガ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/芽 め">め</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1906<br><h1> 邪 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/邪%20%23kanji">Wicked</a></h1>Tusk 。 。 。 city walls。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/邪 じゃ">ジャ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1907<br><h1> 雅 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雅%20%23kanji">Gracious</a></h1>Tusk 。 。 。 an old turkey。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/雅 が">ガ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1908<br><h1> 釈 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釈%20%23kanji">Interpretation</a></h1>Animal tracks 。 。 。 shakuhachi。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/釈 しゃく">シャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1909<br><h1> 番 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/番%20%23kanji">Turn</a></h1>This key word has been chosen for its overlay of several meanings similar to those of the kanji： a turn of duty、 a round、 a number、 and so forth。 Its composite elements： animal tracks 。 。 。 rice field。  As a primitive element、 we choose the image of a pair of dice which it is your turn to throw。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/番 ばん">バン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1910<br><h1> 審 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/審%20%23kanji">Hearing</a></h1>The hearing referred to in this character relates to trials in the courts。 The elements： house 。 。 。 dice。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/審 しん">シン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1911<br><h1> 翻 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/翻%20%23kanji">Flip</a></h1>Dice 。 。 。 feathers。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/翻 ほん">ホン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/翻ひるがえる">ひるがえ－る</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/翻ひるがえす">ひるがえ－す</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1912<br><h1> 藩 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/藩%20%23kanji">Clan</a></h1>Flowers 。 。 。 water 。 。 。 dice。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/藩 はん">ハン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1913<br><h1> 毛 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/毛%20%23kanji">Fur</a></h1>This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of hand to produce fur。 If you reverse your hand and put its palm down、 you will have the side on which fur grows。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/毛 もう">モウ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/毛 け">け</a></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1990<br><h1> 虎 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虎%20%23kanji">Tiger</a></h1>The kanji in this frame recalls the famous Bengali fable about the group of magicians （the magic wand） who decided to make a tiger。 It seems that each of them knew how to make one part of the beast、 so they pooled their talents and brought all the pieces （diced into pieces） together、 at which point the fabricated tiger promptly ate its makers up （the bodiless human legs）。 Whatever the parable’s significance for modern civilization and its arsenals、 it should help with this kanji。 Oh yes、 we should not forget that cliff －like element。 Think of it as an abbreviation of the primitive for zoo （the first and fourth strokes、 actually）、 in order to fit the tiger somewhere into the picture。 In fact、 the abbreviation is perfectly logical、 since the bottom elements usurp the room for the rest of the primitive for zoo。  As a primitive element itself、 the human legs are also swallowed up、 but the meaning of tiger is kept、 and the whole serves as a roof for what comes beneath、 臨、 giving the tiger something else to eat。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虎 こ">コ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虎 とら">とら</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1991<br><h1> 虜 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虜%20%23kanji">Captive</a></h1>Tiger 。 。 。 male。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虜 りょ">リョ</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2></div>

<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1998<br><h1> 虐 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虐%20%23kanji">Tyrannize</a></h1>Tiger 。 。 。 box with a one in it （or a backwards broom、 if that makes it easier）。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虐 ぎゃく">ギャク</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/虐しいたげる">しいた－げる</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>1999<br><h1> 鹿 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鹿%20%23kanji">Deer</a></h1>Drawn on the walls of a complex of caves near Niaux in southern France are a number of animal likenesses dating from the Upper Paleolithic period。 Among them we find pictures of deer、 some of them showing men in deer masks。 By comparing their drawings to real deer、 Stone Age people hoped to acquire power over the animal in the hunt； and by comparing themselves to the deer、 to take on that animal’s characteristics。 But time has locked with a “double－key” （the extra stroke through the element for key） the real secret of this art form from us、 and we can only surmise such meanings。 But more important than the enigmas of the troglodytic mind is the way in which caves、 a double－key、 and comparing gives us the kanji for deer。  As a primitive、 this kanji is abbreviated much the same as the tiger was： the lower element is dropped to leave room for a replacement： 自。 Its meaning、 however、 remains the same。 There are a very few cases （see frame 2002 麗） in which there is no abbreviation。 When this happens、 we may keep the image suggested by the above explanation： painting of a deer。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鹿 しか">しか</a>, <a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/鹿 か">か</a></div>
<style> .mainone { background-color: black; color: white; } .mainone a { color: white; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone a:hover { color:gray; font-size: 1.5em; } .mainone h1 { background-color: black; } .mainone h2 { background-color: orange; width: 50%; margin: auto; } </style><div class = "mainone"><br>2000<br><h1> 薦 </h1></div>	<div class = "mainone"><h1><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薦%20%23kanji">Recommend</a></h1>Flowers 。 。 。 deer 。 。 。 one 。 。 。 tail feathers。 Note the doubling up in these last two elements as in frame 1941 鳥。<br><br><h2>Onyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薦 せん">セン</a><br><br><h2>Kunyomi</h2><a href = "https://www.jisho.org/search/薦すすめる">すす－める</a></div>
